reflections.self_assessment: I created early cover for evil by failing Mission 1 in a way that cast doubt on both myself and Eve, but I didn’t manage to leverage that suspicion later to protect Merlin’s identity or guide the assassin effectively. As Oberon, I should have focused more on reading voting patterns and mission team compositions to infer who my fellow evils and Merlin were, instead of just relying on the mission results themselves. Next time I need to use my own suspicious image more proactively to misdirect good and subtly shield the real Merlin suspect.

player_observations.Bob: Bob played like a classic soft power role—he avoided being on the failed missions while consistently ending up on critical successful ones, especially the last mission. His calm, consistent inclusion in successful teams fit Percival well: he projected trust without over-claiming insight, which helped him stay alive and look like a strong candidate for Merlin.
player_observations.Charlie: Charlie navigated the missions with surgical precision: always on the key successful teams but never appearing too forceful in accusations, which let him guide team choices without drawing a loud Merlin target on himself. His willingness to repeat the same trio (Bob, Charlie, Diana) and argue for their reliability was a very quiet but effective way to steer the game.
player_observations.Diana: Diana’s steady presence on Missions 2, 3, and 4 made her look like a reliable, middle-of-the-pack good player, especially with two clean successes early. Even after being on the failed Mission 4, she didn’t attract lasting suspicion, suggesting her table talk and voting patterns felt consistent and trustworthy to most players.
player_observations.Eve: Eve’s early pairing with me on the failed Mission 1 gave her plausible deniability—she could pivot to blaming me while gradually realigning with whatever the emerging consensus was. As Morgana, she didn’t overplay being insightful; instead she blended in, which helped maintain ambiguity between her and Bob for who might be Merlin/percival.
player_observations.Frank: Frank’s single appearance on the failed Mission 4 was high impact but also high risk, and the fact that the final mission excluded him suggests that failure heavily damaged his perceived reliability. As Mordred, his low table presence (in terms of mission involvement) made it hard for him to shape the narrative later in the game.
player_observations.Grace: Grace only appeared on the final mission but did so in a way that fit a ‘safe late-game inclusion’ profile—someone not heavily implicated in earlier controversies, which made it easier for good to trust her. Her relatively clean record and lack of association with earlier fails helped solidify the final successful team composition.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently on successful teams and maintained a trustworthy table image, which helped Good secure a strong mission record and likely contributed to the Assassin guessing me as Merlin. I could improve by being a bit more vocal about my suspicions and reasoning, especially after the failed Mission 3, to better guide discussion without looking too obvious.

player_observations.Bob: Played a very controlled and subtle Merlin game, consistently landing on correct teams while not drawing too much heat until the end. His leadership on Mission 4, with a fully clean team, showed strong information use and timing.
player_observations.Charlie: As early leader, he started the game on a clean team and projected a generally trustworthy presence. His later inclusion on the successful Mission 4 suggests he adapted well to emerging information and looked genuinely towny.
player_observations.Diana: Was repeatedly on successful teams and helped establish a solid early track record for Good. Her presence on the one failed mission made her a plausible suspect, but overall she maintained a calm, cooperative style that kept her in consideration for good teams.
player_observations.Eve: As Morgana, she seemed to play a more subtle evil game, letting others take center stage in leadership and suspicion. Her deception was good enough that Merlin survived, suggesting she didn’t overforce herself as a target of Percival.
player_observations.Frank: As Mordred, he timed his sabotage on Mission 3 effectively to disrupt the strong early run of Good missions. However, that fail didn’t translate into sustained misdirection, as Good still rebuilt confidence and formed a clean Mission 4 team.
player_observations.Grace: As Oberon, her hidden-evil status likely made her coordination with the other evil players weaker, which showed in the overall mission outcomes. Her impact seemed more muted and less influential on team selections and table direction.

reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated well with Diana on Mission 2 to create a strong early fail and later took a risky but plausible single-fail on Mission 4 to stay in the mix. I need to improve at Merlin-hunting—underestimating Grace’s quiet influence and over-focusing on Eve cost us the game, and I could have done more to frame Grace earlier while keeping my own image cleaner.

player_observations.Bob: Very steady and trust-focused, leaned heavily on the clean track record of the teams he was on and used that to justify the final Mission 5 pick; feels like a player who prefers safe, consensus-driven choices.
player_observations.Charlie: Played an extremely clean, low-drama good role, rarely attracting suspicion and consistently ending up on successful teams, which made them a natural anchor for trust.
player_observations.Diana: Aggressive as evil in Mission 2 with a full triple-fail, showing a willingness to take big swings early; generally projected confidence, which helped keep heat off her later.
player_observations.Eve: Appeared very straightforward and transparent, which made her look like a solid, reliable good player and drew assassin attention; her presence on multiple clean missions reinforced that image.
player_observations.Frank: As Oberon, came across somewhat disconnected from table narrative and reads, which made them hard to coordinate with but also not a central focus of suspicion or trust.
player_observations.Grace: Played an excellent subtle Merlin—avoided being a loud table captain while still nudging teams toward strong good-heavy lineups, especially Mission 3 and the final mission; her influence was felt in outcomes more than in overt table talk, which kept her under the assassin radar.

reflections.self_assessment: As Oberon, I stayed quiet enough that I didn’t draw attention, but I also failed to generate any meaningful confusion or suspicion around the real Merlin, which let good win fairly cleanly. I should have been more proactive in subtly undermining trust in Eve and Grace, even without coordination, and tried to create at least one messy mission to give the assassin a better information landscape.

player_observations.Bob: Played very straightforward and low-drama; his acceptance on the successful missions made him look steadily more trustworthy without needing bold moves.
player_observations.Charlie: As Morgana, he blended in well with the good team energy, especially on Mission 1, and didn’t over-push any hard reads that might have made him look suspicious later.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as calm and reliably good, and her leadership on Mission 2 reinforced that image by proposing a safe team that passed cleanly.
player_observations.Eve: Disguised Merlin very effectively by not coming off as overly controlling, subtly shepherding good teams without making herself an obvious high-value target.
player_observations.Frank: Stayed under the radar as Mordred and didn’t create much noise, but that also meant he didn’t generate the chaos needed to open up multiple plausible Merlin candidates.
player_observations.Grace: Gave off strong ‘likely power role’ vibes at times with confident trust patterns, which made her a tempting but ultimately wrong assassination target.

reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated well with Charlie by doubling up fails on Mission 2, which created strong suspicion on Grace and muddied Merlin’s reads, and I timed my later fail on Mission 4 to close the game without overexposing myself earlier. I could improve by being a bit more visibly torn or hesitant on the critical mission votes to look more genuinely good-aligned, and by more actively steering table talk to frame Diana and Frank rather than mostly letting suspicion develop organically.

player_observations.Bob: You played a very controlled Merlin, often avoiding hard accusations and instead nudging team comps subtly, which helped you stay alive but sometimes left good with less clarity than they needed.
player_observations.Charlie: You leaned into an aggressive evil style, especially by contributing to the double-fail on Mission 2, creating maximum chaos and giving us a lot of cover early.
player_observations.Diana: You tended to trust early successes too much and were slow to fully pivot after Mission 3 failed, which made you look consistently good but also made it easier for evil to sneak onto later teams.
player_observations.Eve: As Oberon, your actions and voting patterns were somewhat off-beat and hard to read, which accidentally helped us by adding noise and making it harder for good to form a clean consensus.
player_observations.Frank: You played very cautiously, often following the emerging table consensus rather than driving it, which made you appear reliably good but also meant your influence on final team selections was limited.
player_observations.Grace: You played an assertive Percival, strongly defending your Merlin reads, but the double-fail on Mission 2 put you under heavy suspicion and you struggled to fully recover your credibility afterward.

reflections.self_assessment: I picked a risky team on Mission 3 that gave evil a clean, low-information fail and I didn’t push hard enough to publicly pressure-test suspects afterward. I did reasonably well staying flexible with my reads and not tunneling too early, but I should have cross-checked team patterns more aggressively with how Diana and Eve were behaving around approvals.

player_observations.Bob: Tended to build fairly safe, consensus-friendly teams, which made him look reliably good, but also let evil hide within his choices. His Mission 4 team showed he was willing to trust too broadly under pressure.
player_observations.Charlie: Played a very smooth, low-conflict game and avoided drawing heat, which is classic Morgana behavior—helpful, agreeable, and just active enough to seem engaged but not suspicious. He blended into good’s general narrative rather than driving his own.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as quietly confident and subtly steered voting without over-explaining, which fit Merlin: she nudged away from danger more than she hard-accused anyone. Her restraint in table talk kept her from being obviously night-killed but may also have limited how much good could coordinate around her signals.
player_observations.Eve: Played actively and seemed to be searching for alignment signals, and her behavior generally tracked with someone trying to protect a hidden information role. At times she appeared torn between following Diana’s soft pushes and her own reads, which created some mixed signals for the table.
player_observations.Frank: Stayed relatively detached and a bit off-beat in his voting and comments, which made him hard to read and fit Oberon’s isolated role. His low-visibility style made it difficult for good to get reliable alignment info from his decisions.
player_observations.Grace: Did a strong job as Mordred of blending in as a reasonable voice and using the Mission 2 fail to sow confusion without over-committing to a narrative. She took advantage of trust given to her early to influence team compositions in subtle but impactful ways.

reflections.self_assessment: As Oberon, I stayed effectively under the radar and let the visible evil roles drive the key mission manipulations, which helped preserve confusion about who was actually causing fails. I could have contributed more by subtly influencing discussion dynamics and sowing targeted doubt around mission 2 and 3 without drawing attention to myself.

player_observations.Bob: Played a cautious Merlin, often positioning himself on early teams and pushing subtly rather than hard-accusing, which helped him avoid looking too obviously informed. However, his consistent inclusion on successful/‘safe’-seeming teams eventually made him look central to good coordination.
player_observations.Charlie: Acted like a protective Percival, frequently aligning with Bob and soft-defending him, which signaled that he likely saw Bob as a power role. His attempts to steer suspicion toward others were measured but a bit transparent once fails started clustering away from Bob.
player_observations.Diana: As Morgana, she leaned into being an assertive voice, offering confident reads that made her look like a strong good player. Her presence on the double-fail mission was risky but her prior social capital helped blunt the suspicion that should have landed on her more heavily.
player_observations.Eve: Played Mordred as a flexible saboteur, willing to be on both risky and safe-looking teams and timing her visible opposition carefully. She contributed to mission fails without becoming the primary scapegoat, which helped maintain uncertainty about where evil was centered.
player_observations.Frank: As good, he seemed genuinely uncertain and followed table consensus more than driving it, which made him look honest but also somewhat manipulable. His early inclusion on teams and lack of strong resistance to evil narratives helped those missions go the way evil wanted.
player_observations.Grace: Adopted a more analytical but slightly reactive good playstyle, often voicing concerns after key mission outcomes rather than pre-emptively. Her suspicion tended to scatter, which relieved pressure on the actual evil players and limited good’s ability to consolidate a clear narrative.

reflections.self_assessment: I think I recovered reasonably well after the disastrous Mission 2 and stayed open to reevaluating my reads, which helped us land on cleaner teams late game. However, I tunneled too hard on the wrong suspects after the double-fail and didn’t push hard enough to protect Frank from being assassinated, especially given how consistently good his team proposals ended up being.

player_observations.Bob: Your play felt very disconnected from the broader evil coordination, which made you swingy in my reads—sometimes looking like a confused good player and sometimes like hidden evil avoiding responsibility.
player_observations.Charlie: You blended in well early, especially sneaking onto the double-fail team without drawing lasting heat, and you didn’t overtalk, which kept your threat level deceptively low.
player_observations.Diana: You came across as steadily pro-good, and your leadership on Missions 4 and 5 felt careful and reasoned, which made your teams look naturally trustworthy.
player_observations.Eve: You leaned into the double-fail on Mission 2 aggressively but then managed to avoid becoming the perpetual scapegoat, which suggests you balanced defense and low profile quite effectively.
player_observations.Frank: Your team choices were very accurate and your table talk had that calm, informed quality that in hindsight clearly signaled Merlin, though in the moment I didn’t do enough to shield you from the assassination.
player_observations.Grace: You projected a strong, confident good vibe from the start, and your alignment with Frank’s reads and team selections was consistent with a protective Percival mindset trying to follow and reinforce Merlin.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed relatively low-profile while still being on multiple mission teams, which helped me appear trustworthy and kept suspicion off me even when missions failed. I could improve by more actively shaping the table talk and framing narratives, especially around who might be Merlin, instead of relying mostly on Grace’s (Morgana’s) presence to draw heat.

player_observations.Bob: Played cautiously and didn’t seem to drive much of the table narrative, which made him look generically good but not central to decision-making.
player_observations.Charlie: As Oberon, came off somewhat disconnected and hard to read, which unintentionally fit a quiet-good or distracted-good profile and didn’t raise major alarms.
player_observations.Diana: As Percival, she leaned into trusting visible ‘power roles’ and seemed fairly comfortable putting me on teams, suggesting I didn’t ping strongly as evil or Merlin to her.
player_observations.Eve: Approached team selection logically and seemed to weigh prior results carefully, but lacked strong, vocal pushes that could have locked in a more coherent good-team block.
player_observations.Frank: As Merlin, he steered missions subtly rather than forcefully, but his repeated inclusion of me and Frank on early and midgame teams suggests he either misread me or was forced to balance keeping cover with influencing outcomes.
player_observations.Grace: As Morgana, she played loudly and assertively, which effectively drew a lot of attention and suspicion toward herself and away from me, helping evil coordinate successful fails without me becoming a prime suspect.

reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated well with the other evil roles by pushing just enough suspicion onto Frank and Diana to keep heat off myself, while still looking flexible in team selections. I could improve by varying my tone when defending Merlin candidates so Percival has a harder time narrowing down between me and the real Merlin, and by engaging more proactively in late-game theory-crafting to subtly steer the narrative.

player_observations.Bob: Tended to play quietly solid evil, blending into the background and letting others drive the accusations, which helped keep long-term suspicion off him.
player_observations.Charlie: Played straightforwardly and relied heavily on mission results rather than social reads, which made them easier to sway with confident table talk.
player_observations.Diana: As Percival, actively tracked Merlin candidates and asked pointed clarifying questions, but sometimes telegraphed where her suspicions lay, giving evil some info about her role.
player_observations.Eve: As Merlin, gave strong but not overly forceful nudges on team composition, managing to appear like a thoughtful good player rather than an obvious power role for much of the game.
player_observations.Frank: Was very trusting early and defended teammates based on gut reads, which made it easier to frame him as suspicious once missions started failing.
player_observations.Grace: As Oberon, played in a way that didn’t strongly align with either side’s visible logic, adding a layer of noise that occasionally helped evil by muddying clear consensus.

reflections.self_assessment: I did well trusting Charlie consistently after the double-success missions and helping to steer teams toward a stable core of Bob/Charlie/Diana, which set up a solid win path. I could improve by pushing harder and earlier against Eve and Alice after Mission 1’s fail, and by more actively protecting Charlie from the assassin by occasionally introducing doubt about whether I might be Merlin.

player_observations.Alice: Took an early leader role and put herself on the failed Mission 1, which made her look evil but also somewhat chaotic and hard to read, fitting Oberon’s hidden-from-evil nature.
player_observations.Charlie: Played a very controlled and consistent Merlin game, quietly guiding team selections toward the correct core without over-speaking and drawing the assassin’s attention.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as naturally trustworthy and steady, which made it easier to keep her in the successful mission core and reinforced the good-team narrative.
player_observations.Eve: Balanced aggression and participation well, but her involvement in the failed first mission and her push on the final team choices gave off subtle evil vibes over time.
player_observations.Frank: Stayed relatively low-impact and less central to team cores, which helped him as Mordred avoid direct suspicion but also limited his influence on team selection.
player_observations.Grace: Felt like a generally cooperative good player whose inclusion on the final mission didn’t raise many alarms, suggesting a straightforward, non-deceptive playstyle.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed relatively subtle as Merlin, nudging teams toward Alice and Diana early and away from the evil-heavy configurations without drawing too much attention, which helped us win and avoided the assassin’s shot. I could improve by seeding a bit more doubt on Frank earlier after Mission 3’s fail, and by giving Percival (Charlie) clearer, but still deniable, signals so they felt more confident about who to trust.

player_observations.Alice: Played very consistently good and unthreatening, which made it easier for me to support her but also made her a natural Merlin target for the assassin. Her calm presence on early successful teams helped solidify trust in her without needing to say much.
player_observations.Charlie: Showed classic Percival behavior: generally trusting of successful teams but occasionally hesitant to hard-clear people, which likely helped avoid making Merlin too obvious. Their leadership on Mission 1 was conservative but solid, anchoring the game in a good start.
player_observations.Diana: Tended to pick safe, previously successful teammates, which strongly contributed to our clean Mission 2. Her choices and table talk felt transparently good, which let me lean into supporting her teams as a Merlin without raising suspicion.
player_observations.Eve: As Morgana, projected a fairly credible “possible Merlin” aura with confident suggestions and willingness to drive the conversation, especially around team composition after the first missions. However, that assertiveness occasionally overreached in subtle ways that made it a bit easier for me to keep her off the most trusted lists.
player_observations.Frank: As Mordred, played a quiet but dangerous game, only visibly spiking on the failed Mission 3 where he could hide behind ambiguity. His prior low-key behavior made that fail harder for good players to pin directly on him, and he was a reasonably good candidate for a future mission if we hadn’t already clinched.
player_observations.Grace: As Oberon, their signals were the most chaotic: not clearly aligned with other evil players and sometimes out of sync with table consensus. That unpredictability reduced their influence over team selection, which helped good overall, but also made it harder to read them cleanly during the game.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed reasonably consistent with my reads and protected Grace well enough that the Assassin picked Eve instead, which helped secure the win. However, I could have pushed harder to clear Charlie and Eve earlier and been more vocal in questioning Alice and Diana after Mission 2’s triple-fail to tighten the circle of suspicion sooner.

player_observations.Alice: Played aggressively and leaned into risky teams, especially putting herself on Mission 2 and 4, which fit a bold evil style that hides behind chaos. Her willingness to eat suspicion after the triple-fail suggested confidence that town would be too divided to fully pin her down.
player_observations.Charlie: Played a steady, low-drama good game, generally accepting reasonable teams and not over-pushing their reads. Their presence on all three successful missions gave them a very ‘anchor’ vibe, but they didn’t strongly leverage that to direct the late-game narrative.
player_observations.Diana: Sold the ‘trusted early good’ image well by being on the clean Mission 1, which set her up as a plausible Merlin/Morgana candidate in my eyes. After Mission 2’s triple-fail, she didn’t over-explain, which actually made her more dangerous because her restraint kept her from looking overtly defensive.
player_observations.Eve: Came across as genuinely good-leaning, especially by being on all three successful missions and not over-claiming insight. Her natural-seeming trust patterns made her a believable information role candidate, which likely contributed to the Assassin mistaking her for Merlin.
player_observations.Frank: As Oberon, his play felt a bit disconnected from the broader evil coordination, which showed in how his suspicion distribution didn’t cleanly protect his teammates. His leadership on the disastrous Mission 2 looked more chaotic than calculated, adding noise rather than a clearly crafted evil narrative.
player_observations.Grace: Played a very measured Merlin, giving just enough guidance to steer good toward strong teams (especially Missions 3 and 5) without looking omniscient. Her balance of soft pushes and willingness to sit back at key moments made it hard for evil to lock onto her, which paid off in the failed assassination.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-team and helped lock in a clean, low-drama path to three successful missions, especially by supporting and trusting the Diana/Bob/Grace team once it showed strong results. I could improve by being more vocal about my reasoning and suspicions during team discussions so that evil has fewer places to hide and Merlin gets more natural cover.

player_observations.Alice: You flew very under the radar, which fit Oberon but also meant you didn’t create much noise or confusion for good to sift through. That low-impact style helped us keep the board state relatively clear.
player_observations.Charlie: You started things off with a clean first mission, which gave you some early credibility as Morgana. Your presence felt cautiously assertive—just enough to seem helpful without over-pushing, which is a strong evil trait.
player_observations.Diana: You played a very solid, trustworthy good game, especially by proposing and sitting on successful missions. Your calm consistency made it easy for me to back your teams with confidence.
player_observations.Eve: You balanced information and subtlety well as Merlin—your influence on team selection was noticeable without being loud enough to trigger an accurate assassination. Your reads seemed to quietly point toward the correct teams without overexposing yourself.
player_observations.Frank: You stayed relatively muted and didn’t draw a lot of heat, which is often effective for Mordred, but it also limited the amount of misleading influence you had on team choices. Your low profile probably helped good keep their trust network clean.
player_observations.Grace: You came across as very town-positive and aligned with good logic, which fit Percival and helped reinforce confidence in the successful teams. Your presence on multiple clean missions also gave strong cover to Merlin by making you an appealing assassination target.

reflections.self_assessment: I identified most of the evil team relatively early, but I struggled to communicate that information subtly enough for good to coordinate without exposing myself. I also failed to steer the table’s suspicions effectively away from the strong evil narratives on Missions 2–4, which let evil control critical team compositions. Next time I should frame my reads more proactively and consistently so that good has a clearer blueprint for safe teams.

player_observations.Alice: You played Mordred very cleanly, blending into discussions and getting onto key teams without drawing much heat, especially on Missions 2 and 4. Your double-fail mission with Charlie was bold yet believable, which created a lot of confusion around which of you (if not both) was evil.
player_observations.Charlie: You leaned into the Morgana ambiguity well, projecting confident reads that made it harder for Percival and others to separate you from me. Your willingness to put multiple evils on Mission 2 and still manage the fallout showed a strong sense of how to shape the narrative afterward.
player_observations.Diana: You played a very straightforward good game, generally trusting early success signals and being cautious but not paralyzed after Mission 2’s fail. Your willingness to go on critical missions, even under some suspicion, kept options open for good but also made it easier for evil to muddy the waters around you.
player_observations.Eve: As Oberon, you managed to stay under the radar enough to get onto two failing missions, which is impressive given your lack of coordination with other evil roles. Your table presence was low-key, which helped you avoid strong suspicion even as you ended up on multiple bad teams.
player_observations.Frank: You played cautiously and felt fairly transparent as good, which is helpful for Merlin but unfortunately didn’t convert into you driving strong alternative team proposals late. When under pressure, you seemed more reactive than agenda-setting, which made it easier for evil voices to dominate mission selection.
player_observations.Grace: You leaned into the Percival role actively, but the Morgana/Merlin ambiguity clearly pulled you off the correct alignment reads at key moments. Your strong, confident pushes were impactful, which is great when you’re right, but in this game they unintentionally amplified evil narratives around the failing missions.

reflections.self_assessment: I trusted my early reads too much and didn’t sufficiently re-evaluate after Missions 2 and 3, especially once overlapping suspicions on Alice and Charlie emerged. I also failed to strongly contest the Mission 4 team composition despite it containing multiple high-risk players, which let evil close out the game.

player_observations.Alice: Played a solidly low-key good game and absorbed suspicion without over-defending, which unfortunately made her an easy scapegoat for evil. Her willingness to go on risky teams made her look opportunistic, but that also helped keep missions moving.
player_observations.Charlie: Blended in very well as Morgana, staying active in discussion without pushing too hard, which made his accusations seem reasonable rather than agenda-driven. His presence on Mission 3 and 4 teams while still feeling ‘plausibly good’ was a key factor in evil’s success.
player_observations.Diana: As Merlin, she was subtle to the point of sometimes being hard to distinguish from a cautious generic good player, which protected her but didn’t clearly steer the table away from bad teams. Her soft pushes were accurate in hindsight, but they weren’t forceful enough to flip consensus at crucial votes.
player_observations.Eve: As Percival, she appeared genuinely conflicted between possible Merlin candidates, which made her reads feel honest but also somewhat scattered. Her uncertainty reduced the protective pressure on the real Merlin and gave evil more room to shape the narrative.
player_observations.Frank: Played a very quiet, somewhat chaotic Oberon game, creating just enough confusion that his alignment was hard to lock in either way. His early Mission 1 success with me built a misleading sense of trust that carried later into Mission 4.
player_observations.Grace: As Mordred, she did an excellent job anchoring suspicion elsewhere after the failed Mission 2, deflecting blame onto her teammates and the mission composition instead of herself. Her calm, analytical tone made her seem like a ‘voice of reason,’ which helped evil control the mid-game team selections.

reflections.self_assessment: I got too complacent after Mission 1’s clean success and didn’t push hard enough to block the Mission 2 team with both Frank and Eve, even though I knew at least one evil was sneaking into early missions. I also failed to clearly and consistently steer teams away from the Diana/Eve combination without looking like I had extra info, which let evil stack Mission 3 and set up the loss on Mission 4.

player_observations.Alice: You played Oberon very quietly and stayed under the radar; your lack of strong agenda made you look like a slightly disengaged good player rather than hidden evil. Because you weren’t pushing hard on team compositions, you never drew the kind of suspicion that usually hits evil early.
player_observations.Charlie: As Percival, you were actively trying to solve the Merlin/Morgana puzzle, but your reads on Diana vs. me seemed to drift toward trusting Diana too much. Your willingness to back risky teams made it easier for evil to pass questionable lineups without heavy scrutiny.
player_observations.Diana: Your Morgana play was strong: you inserted yourself into key teams and blended confident table talk with just enough logic to seem like a good strategist. The double-fail on Mission 3 was set up well by your earlier reasonable behavior, so when it finally blew up, suspicion spread wide instead of landing squarely on you.
player_observations.Eve: You played Mordred as a flexible support evil, often taking moderate, non-flashy positions that kept you from being the obvious suspect. Your inclusion on the Mission 2 fail was subtle enough that it looked like it could easily have been Frank or even me misjudging, which gave you long-term cover.
player_observations.Frank: You played like a very straightforward good player, backing teams that made intuitive sense rather than over-the-top ‘safe’ ones, which accidentally gave evil more room on Missions 2 and 4. Your clean behavior on Mission 1 helped you look trustworthy, but also made your later approvals more influential in pushing through a bad team.
player_observations.Grace: You were relatively cautious and tried to avoid loudly anchoring on hard reads, which kept you looking consistently good but also limited your ability to stop bad teams. Your tendency to follow the table’s momentum rather than drive it meant that once the discussion leaned toward trusting the wrong people, you went along instead of pushing back.

reflections.self_assessment: Staying low-key as Oberon worked well; I wasn’t heavily suspected or used as a key data point, which helped chaos and let the visible evils drive the narrative. I could improve by creating slightly clearer but still ambiguous voting patterns that subtly mislead good without making me stand out, especially around Missions 4 and 5 where good consolidated too much trust.

player_observations.Alice: Played as a generally trusted anchor, especially after being on a clean Mission 1 and later clean missions, which made others comfortable reusing her on teams. She seemed to lean on mission results more than social reads, which made her slow to revise trust once she’d mentally cleared someone.
player_observations.Charlie: As Mordred, Charlie applied pressure effectively on Mission 2 by helping generate a strong fail while not becoming the obvious culprit afterward. His presence on that early failed team created a lot of noisy WIFOM that never fully got resolved against him.
player_observations.Diana: Diana played a cautious, logic-oriented good, trying to reconcile mission histories systematically, especially later in the game. That methodical style made her teams look reasoned and safe, which ironically helped solidify the final, wrong trust configuration.
player_observations.Eve: As Morgana, Eve embraced the high-impact evil role well by contributing to the double-fail on Mission 2 and adding confusion around who the power roles might be. Her willingness to be on a suspicious early fail helped take heat off later evil decision points.
player_observations.Frank: As Merlin, Frank hid well enough during the missions to avoid obvious outing, maintaining a believable good perspective that didn’t scream ‘information advantage’. However, his visible centrality and influence on the final successful teams ultimately gave the assassin enough of a signal to pick him correctly.
player_observations.Grace: Grace played an engaged Percival, trying to parse between Merlin and Morgana signals, which contributed to trusting the wrong structure by the end. Her early inclusion on a clean Mission 1 and later successes made her reads feel very credible to the table, amplifying any misreads she had about the power roles.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed reasonably consistent with my reads and tried to balance caution with mission risk, but I didn’t press hard enough on the patterns of who kept getting onto failing teams. I should have been more suspicious of Alice and Grace earlier and coordinated more explicitly around protecting Frank once his behavior started to look like Merlin.

player_observations.Alice: Very smooth and trustworthy table presence; getting on multiple critical teams without drawing strong suspicion suggests she’s good at blending in and avoiding direct confrontation.
player_observations.Charlie: Stayed relatively under the radar and didn’t strongly drive team compositions, which helped Oberon go mostly unnoticed and made it harder for good to clearly categorize him.
player_observations.Diana: Played actively and looked genuinely engaged in solving the puzzle, which fit Percival well; her apparent trust in certain players influenced the table, even if it didn’t ultimately land on the right evil combo.
player_observations.Eve: Her play read as genuinely good and transparent, and the mission 2 setup with her on it felt more unfortunate than suspicious; she seemed to make logical arguments but maybe didn’t push hard enough against recurring evil picks.
player_observations.Frank: Came across as thoughtful and information-driven, consistent with Merlin trying to steer outcomes subtly; he tried to avoid being too obvious, but in hindsight his team preferences were often closer to correct than the table gave him credit for.
player_observations.Grace: Assertive and confident in team building, which worked well to guide outcomes toward evil; as Morgana she leaned into a persuasive, central role that made her look more like a power good role than a potential source of fails.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed mostly under the radar as Mordred and let the louder suspicions swirl around others, which helped keep heat off me on the crucial missions. I could improve by taking a slightly more active role in steering team compositions so that evil has more controlled influence without making my agenda too obvious.

player_observations.Alice: Aggressive and proactive in shaping teams, which fit Morgana well by drawing suspicion while confusing Merlin/percival reads.
player_observations.Charlie: Played straightforwardly and seemed to trust early mission structures, which made them appear generically good but not strongly persuasive.
player_observations.Diana: Often tried to reason things out publicly and cross-check information, consistent with a power role trying to protect Merlin subtly.
player_observations.Eve: Very measured in accusations and approvals, rarely overcommitting; this cautious style matched a Merlin who was trying hard not to get caught.
player_observations.Frank: Flexible and somewhat trusting in early missions, which made them an attractive inclusion for teams without generating much suspicion.
player_observations.Grace: Unpredictable voting and team preferences created noise, which accidentally helped evil by making it harder for good to form a clear consensus.

reflections.self_assessment: I did well subtly steering teams toward the known-good core (Bob, Diana, and eventually Grace) while avoiding drawing too much attention, as shown by the assassin choosing Bob instead of me. I could improve by managing suspicion around mission 4 more carefully—finding ways to push back on including Frank without making my knowledge look too precise.

player_observations.Alice: Aggressive early sabotage on Mission 1 set a deceptive tone, and afterward she blended into the background reasonably well for an Oberon, not over-coordinating with the visible evil patterns.
player_observations.Bob: Played assertively and logically, which fit Percival well and made him a natural focal point for team coordination and, ultimately, a plausible Merlin target for the assassin.
player_observations.Diana: Consistently aligned with good logic and seemed comfortable forming a stable core once Missions 2 and 3 succeeded, projecting a straightforward, trustworthy playstyle.
player_observations.Eve: Opened with a risky early fail on Mission 1 but then leaned into a more talkative, influential style that fit Morgana, trying to appear like a strong information role to draw Percival’s and the assassin’s attention.
player_observations.Frank: Stayed relatively under the radar until Mission 4, where the single fail suggested a more cautious evil approach, taking the shot when added to an otherwise trusted team.
player_observations.Grace: Came in late but slotted neatly into the established good bloc on Mission 5, following the emerging logic and not overcomplicating decisions, which helped secure the final success.

reflections.self_assessment: I did well at quietly protecting who I thought was Merlin and not over-sharing my suspicions, which helped keep heat off Bob late game. I could improve by being more explicit in subtly signaling my Merlin read to trusted players earlier, and by narrowing down evil candidates faster after Mission 3 failed.

player_observations.Alice: Played very cleanly and consistently on early missions, which made you a natural town core candidate and a plausible Merlin target for the Assassin. Your calm, low-drama style made it harder to distinguish you from power roles.
player_observations.Bob: You balanced giving just enough guidance to steer teams without looking omniscient, which is why the Assassin misfired on Alice. Your reads seemed carefully paced—never too early, never too strong—which is excellent Merlin discipline.
player_observations.Diana: You projected a very trustworthy, straightforward good vibe and your leadership on Mission 2 reinforced that image. Your willingness to go on repeated teams without over-defending yourself helped stabilize the good team’s trust network.
player_observations.Eve: You played a subtle Morgana, generating just enough doubt around good players without loudly pushing bad teams, which kept suspicion from locking onto you early. Your ambiguity about reads made you a viable Merlin candidate from my perspective for a while.
player_observations.Frank: Your play around the failed Mission 3 was sharp from an evil perspective, since you didn’t come off as the obvious source of the fail and left room for paranoia on others. The way you blended into earlier missions made the later suspicion more distributed rather than focused squarely on you.
player_observations.Grace: You had a more off-beat, somewhat disconnected pattern of interaction that fit Oberon—occasionally suspicious but not coordinated with the other evils. That slight misalignment in tempo with table consensus made you hard to read but also kept you from being the primary focus of fear.

reflections.self_assessment: I consistently pushed for and supported mostly clean teams, especially around missions 1, 3, and 5, which helped build trust in me as a reliable good player. I could improve by being more vocal in explicitly mapping out my suspicions and role-reads earlier, which might have further constrained evil’s options and clarified endgame team decisions.

player_observations.Alice: Tended to steer mid-game team selections in ways that subtly protected fellow evil, especially on Mission 2 and 4, while maintaining a fairly reasonable table presence that didn’t draw too much suspicion.
player_observations.Bob: Played a cautious, information-gathering style, often deferring to perceived clears and trying to keep multiple options open, which fit well with a Percival mindset but sometimes made it harder to read his true convictions.
player_observations.Diana: Showed early-game confidence and willingness to be on critical teams, which helped evil get a strong opening on Mission 2, but that aggression also created some longer-term suspicion.
player_observations.Eve: Came across as straightforward and consistent, especially on the successful missions, which made her look reliably good and a reasonable teammate for the later critical missions despite drawing the assassin’s suspicion.
player_observations.Frank: Played more unpredictably and somewhat disconnected from the emerging consensus, which fit Oberon’s isolated position but also made it harder for both sides to cleanly interpret his actions.
player_observations.Grace: Managed information very carefully, supporting good teams at key moments without over-pushing reads, which kept her Merlin identity well hidden while still guiding missions toward success.

reflections.self_assessment: I leaned into a very safe, low-suspicion style as Morgana, which helped all three missions pass and kept me off most people’s radar. However, I did not create enough ambiguity around Merlin’s identity—Eve stayed too clean while Grace looked more like Percival than Merlin—so I need to more actively fake Merlin-like reads and draw suspicion away from the real Merlin.

player_observations.Alice: Played very quietly and independently, which fit Oberon well but also made it hard for evil to coordinate reads around her; her low profile kept her from being a major focus of discussion.
player_observations.Bob: Came across as straightforward and reliably good-aligned, especially by accepting and succeeding on early teams; his non-flashy style made him feel trustworthy without attracting assassin heat.
player_observations.Diana: Led and joined multiple successful missions with a calm, logical presence, which projected strong village vibes; her team selections helped solidify a clean core for good.
player_observations.Eve: Maintained a composed, subtly guiding presence that steered teams correctly without over-claiming insight, which is classic strong Merlin play; her restraint made her hard to pin as the obvious power role.
player_observations.Frank: Stayed relatively under the radar for a key evil role, not drawing heavy suspicion but also not creating enough chaos or misdirection to threaten good’s emerging consensus.
player_observations.Grace: Projected a very protown, confident table presence that looked more like a protected power role than a hidden Merlin; her clear, assertive reasoning made her a natural (but ultimately wrong) assassin target.

reflections.self_assessment: I leaned into looking like a cautious but flexible good player, especially around Mission 2, which helped keep suspicion spread across multiple people instead of focused on me and Alice. I could have done a better job subtly nudging Percival’s read more strongly onto me over Bob, to create more late-game doubt if Merlin had tried to hard-clear anyone.

player_observations.Alice: Played Mordred quietly but effectively, staying just active enough to avoid being an obvious lurker while not taking loud leadership spots that could draw Merlin’s focus.
player_observations.Bob: Played Merlin conservatively, signaling reads mostly through team choices rather than open accusations, which kept him alive but also left some ambiguity for evil to exploit.
player_observations.Diana: Approached the game with a straightforward, logic-driven style and seemed to trust structural reasoning over social reads, which made her slower to pivot when the mission results started pointing in unexpected directions.
player_observations.Eve: As Oberon, their signals were noisy and somewhat disconnected from the main evil strategy, but the general confusion this created indirectly helped keep good from cleanly coordinating.
player_observations.Frank: Showed a preference for clear, reasoned arguments and appeared reluctant to commit hard to accusations without strong mission evidence, which made him look reliably good but not especially disruptive to evil.
player_observations.Grace: As Percival, she was very focused on identifying Merlin through subtle behavior, but her caution made her slow to act decisively on those reads, giving evil more room to maneuver around her suspicions.

reflections.self_assessment: I did well coordinating subtle fails with Grace and not over-explaining my logic, which helped maintain doubt about my alignment and kept suspicion spread around. I could improve by more actively shaping good-team narratives earlier, as I mostly reacted to others’ accusations instead of driving misreads proactively.

player_observations.Alice: Played cautiously and seemed to lean heavily on voting patterns; once she tentatively locked in a narrative, she stuck with it and was slower to reassess when new info appeared.
player_observations.Bob: Assertive in table talk and tried to structure logical frameworks for trust, but occasionally anchored too hard on early impressions, which made him exploitable for manipulation.
player_observations.Diana: As Merlin, she was careful not to be too obvious, nudging the table with questions rather than hard accusations; however, her consistent soft distrust of the right people nearly gave away her role.
player_observations.Eve: As Percival, she actively searched for Merlin but put a bit too much weight on tone and confidence, which made her vulnerable to Morgana/Merlin confusion and subtle misdirection.
player_observations.Frank: As Oberon, he played unpredictably and didn’t clearly align with other evil players, which created some chaos but also made it harder for good to form airtight trust circles.
player_observations.Grace: As Mordred, she blended in well with the logical core of the table, timing her fail nicely and maintaining a calm, reasoned demeanor that made her one of the least-suspected players through most of the game.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly trusted Bob as likely Merlin reasonably early, but I didn’t do enough to actively steer the table away from Diana and Eve once doubts started to spread. I also should have pushed harder against the mission 4 team composition and articulated clearer, more structured reasoning about why including Eve (after mission 2) and Diana (after mission 3) was too risky.

player_observations.Alice: Stayed quiet and low-impact, which fit Oberon well—didn’t strongly sway team picks but also didn’t draw suspicion, making it easy to forget to scrutinize her alignment.
player_observations.Bob: Played a very cautious and non-accusatory Merlin, often preferring to hint through team preferences rather than hard pushes, which made it tougher for good to fully lock onto his information but also kept him relatively safe.
player_observations.Diana: Played an assertive, persuasive style as Morgana, confidently volunteering for teams and framing her presence as ‘stabilizing,’ which helped mask her after the double-fail on mission 3 by shifting blame onto team construction logic.
player_observations.Eve: Adopted a flexible, adaptable approach—willing to be on early missions and then subtly leaning into doubt once mission 2 failed, using that single fail to seed plausible narratives without becoming the loudest voice.
player_observations.Frank: Came across as earnest and straightforward, but his early willingness to team with Eve and then later to accept riskier team compositions made it easier for evil to slip onto missions without heavy resistance.
player_observations.Grace: Played a more analytical but somewhat reactive game, often commenting on the logic of past missions rather than forcefully proposing alternative teams, which meant her good instincts had less impact on actual team selections.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed well hidden as Mordred, letting others (especially Morgana) draw more suspicion while I avoided being a lightning rod for accusations. I could improve by being more active in shaping late-game team compositions and narratives instead of relying so heavily on Merlin being exposed and the assassin finishing the job.

player_observations.Alice: Tended to get picked frequently and leveraged that trust well, but the repeated inclusion on late successful missions suggests she sometimes defaults to safe, familiar teams.
player_observations.Bob: As Oberon, created some chaotic information with the fail on Mission 3 without clear coordination, which made him look independently suspicious but also muddied the waters in a useful way for evil.
player_observations.Diana: Played conservatively and seemed risk-averse with team choices, which helped her appear consistently good but may have limited her willingness to push for controversial but informative teams.
player_observations.Eve: As Morgana, did strong early disruptive work (notably on Mission 2 with the double fail) and leaned into a more visible, active role that helped draw Merlin’s attention and suspicion toward herself.
player_observations.Frank: As Merlin, read the evil team well enough to get assassinated, but was cautious in how strongly he pushed against specific players, which helped him survive to the end yet still left a trail the assassin could follow.
player_observations.Grace: As Percival, appeared to trust Frank and Alice quite a bit, and her choices on early and mid-game teams contributed to Frank surviving while still looking sufficiently central to the good strategy.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed reasonably quiet and let suspicion swirl around others, which helped evil win without drawing too much attention to myself, especially on Mission 4 when I could safely play fail with cover from other evils. I could improve by more actively shaping the table talk and reads earlier in the game, so that by the time the later missions came around I had more influence over who was trusted or doubted.

player_observations.Alice: Alice played Mordred very smoothly, getting onto multiple teams and blending in as a consistent, low-drama pick while still participating in key fails. Her positioning made her look like a safe default choice for leaders who didn’t have strong alternative reads.
player_observations.Bob: Bob’s play was straightforwardly good-aligned and fairly trusting, which made him read as genuine but also a bit easy to steer. He didn’t push hard meta-narratives, which reduced his impact but also kept him from becoming a major target of suspicion.
player_observations.Diana: As Percival, Diana tried to read Merlin from mission outcomes but didn’t aggressively hard-clear or hard-push anyone, which limited Percival’s protective impact. Her early willingness to put Frank on Mission 1 helped establish him as a trusted figure later.
player_observations.Eve: Eve’s leadership on Mission 2 showed some willingness to experiment with team comps but ultimately included the wrong mix, which hurt good’s info and trust network. She seemed to balance caution with a bit of risk, but not in a way that strongly anchored the good team’s reads.
player_observations.Frank: Frank, as Merlin, was cautious and didn’t overly reveal his knowledge, which helped him survive but left good without a strong, assertive guiding voice. His inclusion patterns did suggest some hidden info, but not clearly enough to pull the table firmly toward a mostly-good team.
player_observations.Grace: Grace as Morgana projected a convincingly Merlin-adjacent aura, inserting herself into mission discussions and getting onto the critical Mission 4 team. Her willingness to take the spotlight and coordinate a heavy fail there was decisive for the evil win.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly knew Alice had to be evil after Mission 1 failed with just the two of us, but I didn't push that read hard or clearly enough to shape future team selections. I also didn’t anchor strongly enough on the fully good Mission 2 team as a likely core, which let evil sneak back onto teams. Next time I should communicate my logic more explicitly and be more assertive about locking in provably good groups.

player_observations.Alice: Comfortable taking early mission leadership and hiding in plain sight, even after a suspicious fail that heavily implicated her; she relied on others not hard-clearing you from Mission 1 info.
player_observations.Bob: Played a measured, low-key evil game, blending into reasonable team compositions and leveraging others’ trust rather than driving the table; his late leadership on Mission 4 was accepted too easily.
player_observations.Diana: Played like a cautious but logical good/percival, often willing to go on teams but not overasserting; seemed to trust structural evidence (like Mission 2) but didn’t fully force it through table resistance.
player_observations.Eve: As Merlin, stayed subtle and avoided overt hard-pushes that would out her role, giving light pressure rather than strong vetoes; this preserved her cover but may have allowed one too many risky teams to pass.
player_observations.Frank: Came across as straightforward and earnest, which made him broadly trusted; he went on multiple key teams and seemed more reactive than directive in table talk.
player_observations.Grace: As Oberon, managed to avoid huge attention while still ending up on the crucial failing Mission 4 team; played ambiguously enough that their alignment wasn’t clearly solved despite limited visible coordination.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently aligned with good teams after Mission 2, building trust with Bob and especially Charlie, which helped stabilize team selections for the crucial later missions. I could improve by pushing harder to scrutinize Eve and Alice earlier—Mission 1’s fail and Mission 4’s fail both offered data I was a bit slow to convert into strong table-wide arguments.

player_observations.Alice: Opened with a risky Mission 1 that failed, then didn’t convincingly distance herself from that result, which made her look suspicious but also somewhat disconnected from coordinated evil play—very fitting for Oberon.
player_observations.Bob: Played like a classic cautious Percival: he consistently grouped with Charlie and me on Missions 2 and 3, and generally defended Charlie as trustworthy without over-claiming or hard-clearing anyone.
player_observations.Charlie: Projected calm, informed confidence in team selection, especially around Missions 2 and 3; his pushes for stable, low-variance good teams were subtle but clearly Merlin-like in hindsight.
player_observations.Eve: Mixed aggression and opportunism—early willingness to go on the failing Mission 1 and then leading the final mission with a slightly shifted team suggested she was trying to reshape the narrative while staying just within the bounds of plausible good play.
player_observations.Frank: Stayed relatively under the radar and only appeared in a single failing mission, which fit Mordred well: present just enough to create confusion without drawing strong accusations.
player_observations.Grace: Played straightforwardly and acceptingly of the proven core of Bob/Charlie/me, signaling a low-information good perspective and helping lock in a clean final mission lineup.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently trustworthy on missions and kept my logic grounded, which helped reinforce confidence in teams I was on. I could improve by being more vocal about deducing that Frank was likely the Mission 3 saboteur and by articulating clearer suspicions earlier, rather than mostly confirming others’ reads.

player_observations.Alice: Tended to end up on early successful teams, which made her look very clean and a natural target for the Assassin’s Merlin guess; her play came across as steady and non-flashy.
player_observations.Bob: Played Merlin very subtly, only appearing on safe teams and not drawing much attention, which clearly worked since the Assassin guessed wrong; his influence on team selection felt quiet but accurate.
player_observations.Charlie: As an early leader, he formed a clean Mission 1 team, suggesting solid initial instincts; his playstyle felt proactive but not overbearing, fitting well with a loyal support/reading role as Percival.
player_observations.Eve: Never appearing on a mission kept mechanical suspicion low but forced her to rely purely on table talk to misdirect; her impact likely came more from narrative shaping than from mission results.
player_observations.Frank: Joining Mission 3 and causing the lone fail points to a calculated willingness to strike only when it mattered; his earlier absence from missions helped him stay under the radar until that point.
player_observations.Grace: As Oberon, she stayed completely off all missions and thus never had to reveal alignment through cards, which fit a very low-profile, information-denying style that made her hard for good to read at all.

reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated well with the evil team on Mission 2, making it look like a chaotic pile of fails rather than a clean evil signal, and I stayed reasonably unexposed afterward. However, I clearly failed to sell myself as the more likely Merlin to Bob/Assassin compared to Grace, and I didn’t invest enough in creating a long-term 'Merlin-looking' narrative early in the game. Next time I should focus more on seeding consistent, trackable 'good logic' that diverts suspicion from the real Merlin.

player_observations.Alice: Played very aggressively evil on Mission 2 with the triple fail but then blended in well enough later to get back on teams, suggesting comfort with taking short-term suspicion for longer-term ambiguity. Seems willing to be on risky missions and trusts in social talk to smooth things over afterward.
player_observations.Bob: Showed a strong inclination toward logical team construction and seemed to anchor heavily on mission outcomes, but was misled in the assassin phase about Merlin’s identity. As Percival, they appeared uncertain between me and Grace, which indicates they weigh behavioral clues but can be thrown off by deliberate theatrics.
player_observations.Charlie: Played very straightforwardly, with choices that consistently aligned with a good perspective and little apparent deception. Often seemed to go with the emerging table consensus rather than driving it, which made them appear reliably good but not overly influential.
player_observations.Eve: Looked very clean after leading a successful Mission 1 and staying on later successful teams, which naturally made them a tempting Merlin candidate. Their play was solidly pro-good but not overly showy with deductions, which unintentionally helped sell the illusion that they might be a cautious Merlin.
player_observations.Frank: As Oberon, their contributions were a bit disjointed and didn’t clearly signal alignment, which fit the hidden-evil role but made coordination harder for the rest of evil. The hard fail on Mission 2 showed they were willing to commit, but their table talk didn’t strongly help frame suspicion on the right good players.
player_observations.Grace: Played an impressively low-key Merlin, guiding team selections just enough to keep good on track without drawing obvious attention. Her subtle steering toward successful missions while avoiding overt, confident reads on evil made her very hard to pinpoint in the assassin phase.

reflections.self_assessment: I played a solid, low-profile good role, supporting clean teams without drawing too much suspicion, especially by backing and then reusing the successful Mission 2 team. I could improve by being more vocal in publicly questioning alternative team compositions to generate more information about the evil players’ preferences, rather than mostly reinforcing already-safe patterns.

player_observations.Alice: Stayed quite hidden as Oberon, which suggests a naturally quiet or reactive style that doesn’t strongly steer team choices. This made it harder to read her alignment, but also meant she didn’t strongly aid her fellow evil players.
player_observations.Bob: Consistently ended up on successful teams and projected a reliable, cooperative presence, which fit well with a straightforward good playstyle. Likely to be trusted in future games if he maintains that calm, steady pattern.
player_observations.Charlie: As Morgana, led Mission 1 successfully, which is a strong way to build early credibility and appear safely good. Tends to play assertively but within the bounds of what looks reasonable, making their evil play more subtle and dangerous.
player_observations.Eve: Played Merlin very carefully by not over-pushing too aggressively while still helping guide strong, overlapping good teams. Her influence was felt more in who kept getting included than in loud accusations, which helped her avoid the assassin’s shot.
player_observations.Frank: As Mordred, blended in enough that there wasn’t an obvious public pushback against him, but also didn’t manage to derail the clean team pattern once it formed. His style seems more opportunistic than driving, waiting for openings rather than forcing chaos.
player_observations.Grace: As Percival, navigated the Merlin/Morgana ambiguity reasonably well but still ended up being picked as the assassin’s target, suggesting she projected more ‘Merlin energy’ than intended. Her playstyle appears active and engaged, which is great for good, but she may need to slightly tone down how confidently she signals reads in Merlin-heavy setups.

reflections.self_assessment: I trusted the wrong people at key moments, especially letting Eve onto my mission and not pushing harder against Alice after the double-fail in Mission 2, which contributed directly to the later fails. I did reasonably well at staying open to new information between missions, but I need to be more decisive in locking in likely evil candidates earlier and arguing more clearly for safer team compositions.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very controlled game as Mordred, staying just credible enough to keep getting on teams even after the disastrous double-fail on Mission 2, and managed to sneak onto the critical Mission 4 team for the final fail.
player_observations.Bob: As Merlin, Bob consistently positioned himself near the center of most mission teams and subtly steered compositions toward safer options, but his signaling wasn’t quite strong or clear enough to pull the table away from including the hidden evils late.
player_observations.Charlie: As Morgana, Charlie did a good job muddying the Merlin read early, especially by being on the double-fail Mission 2 team in a way that didn’t immediately clear up whether he was evil or just unlucky.
player_observations.Eve: As Oberon, Eve’s presence on my Mission 3 team created a pivotal fail; their play came off as somewhat erratic or hard to read, which helped them slip into teams without generating enough resistance.
player_observations.Frank: Frank played a fairly straightforward good-game, generally not attracting much suspicion and ending up on the final mission as a trusted choice, which indicates solid, low-drama table presence.
player_observations.Grace: As Percival, Grace’s early involvement on the Mission 2 fail team put her in a tricky trust position, yet she still managed to maintain enough credibility that people didn’t hard-clear her as evil, suggesting her Merlin-reading and table talk were somewhat conflicted but not blatantly off.

reflections.self_assessment: I identified Grace and Charlie as highly suspicious fairly early but struggled to communicate that without overexposing myself, which let evil steer missions late. I also failed to reassess Frank properly after Mission 4 and didn’t push harder for safer team comps when the pattern of single-fail missions shifted to a double-fail. Next time I should more explicitly frame my reads as ‘process of elimination’ logic so town can follow them without it screaming Merlin.

player_observations.Alice: Played very cautiously and looked consistently towny, but didn’t seem to fully leverage that towncredit to push hard for teams she trusted. Tended to follow emerging consensus rather than drive it, which made it easier for evil to keep control of critical team votes.
player_observations.Bob: Came across as earnest and proactive, often taking initiative on team discussions. However, he seemed quite trusting of early narratives and was slow to pivot after the Mission 3 and 4 fails, which evil used to keep suspicion away from the real threats.
player_observations.Charlie: Blended in well as evil by not being too loud or too quiet, maintaining a believable mid-activity profile. Managed to stay off the most obvious suspicion lists despite being on the failing Mission 3 team, which shows good timing in when to push and when to sit back.
player_observations.Eve: Seemed to be actively hunting for Merlin and over-focusing on subtle tone/read differences, which sometimes pulled attention away from solving team compositions. As Percival, their uncertainty about which of Charlie/Grace/Alice might be Merlin-like let evil get more space than ideal.
player_observations.Frank: Played somewhat erratically, which made him hard to read and unintentionally gave cover to evil decisions. His presence on the double-fail Mission 4 team added confusion rather than clarity, as his chaotic style made it tricky to separate genuine town noise from potential evil intent.
player_observations.Grace: Very effective as evil at looking reasonable and measured, especially when leading Mission 2 and navigating its single fail. She positioned herself as a logical voice in discussions and avoided being overly forceful, which let her guide outcomes without attracting the level of suspicion her role warranted.

reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated well with Eve to create conflicting signals around Merlin/evil placement, and my double-fail on Mission 3 was timed to maximize confusion while still looking like it could be a coordinated trap. I could improve by managing my table image earlier so that my eventual fail participation felt more reluctantly forced rather than potentially proactive, and by more explicitly nudging town reads toward Alice and Grace to shield Eve more cleanly.

player_observations.Alice: Played very quietly and ambiguously, which fit Oberon but also made you an easy late-game shrug read rather than a strongly positioned misclear or suspect.
player_observations.Bob: You projected a calm, consistent logic that fit Merlin well; your team suggestions were usually reasonable, though occasionally a bit conservative, which helped you avoid immediate suspicion.
player_observations.Charlie: You leaned into an active, investigative style consistent with Percival, but seemed occasionally torn between trusting Bob and testing alternative narratives, which introduced just enough doubt for evil to exploit.
player_observations.Eve: You balanced aggression and restraint well, taking key mission spots without overexplaining your reasoning, and your single fail on Mission 2 set up excellent long-term ambiguity.
player_observations.Frank: Your play felt very transparently good-aligned—especially your participation on Mission 1 and your later reasoning—which made you a stabilizing voice but also somewhat predictable for evil to work around.
player_observations.Grace: You were cautious with approvals and seemed to rely heavily on social reads; that caution was good for avoiding obvious traps but sometimes left your influence on team selection a bit muted.

reflections.self_assessment: I did a solid job of trusting the right people by the end, helping to form the all-good teams on Missions 4 and 5, which showed I was reading the mission results reasonably well. I could improve by pushing harder, earlier, on the logical implications of Mission 2’s double fail and Mission 3’s single fail, and by being more vocal in thread so that Merlin (Frank) had more cover and the assassin had a harder time locking onto him.

player_observations.Alice: You played a very calm, trustworthy good game, and your inclusion on both a failed (Mission 2) and then later successful teams made you look ambiguously but ultimately reasonably good. You seemed willing to go on risky teams early but then settled into a more logic-based approach later, which helped us converge on the right group.
player_observations.Bob: Your Oberon play was low-key and blended in well; the single fail on Mission 3 with you on it didn’t immediately scream ‘evil’ because the team also looked plausible. You didn’t overtalk or oversteer, which made it harder for good to confidently pin you down as the source of the fail.
player_observations.Charlie: You leaned into the chaos as Mordred on the early critical Mission 2, where the double fail really muddied the waters and made that whole trio look suspect. Your positioning afterward stayed just reasonable enough that you weren’t forced into the spotlight, which was effective evil play.
player_observations.Eve: As Morgana, you contributed to the high confusion from Mission 2 and then managed to stay relatively unexposed afterward, which helped keep suspicion distributed. Your alignment with evil narratives without being loud or flashy helped protect the actual failers on that mission.
player_observations.Frank: Your Merlin game was strong on reading the table and steering us toward the correct good block by Missions 4 and 5, but your accuracy and confidence made you look like a standout good player and thus an attractive assassination target. A touch more hesitation or occasional misdirection might have given you better cover without sacrificing too much team quality.
player_observations.Grace: You played a very logical and persuasive Percival, and your leadership on Mission 1 plus later team choices helped set a trustworthy tone around you. Your reads and interactions around Frank likely contributed to the assassin narrowing in on him, which is a compliment to how convincingly you treated him as cleared but also a small vulnerability in Merlin protection.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly trusted Frank early and kept him on teams, but I didn’t leverage my Percival information strongly enough to push back harder against Grace’s influence and Alice’s growing trust. I also failed to clearly communicate a consistent good-team narrative, which let evil coordinate quietly while good stayed fragmented.

player_observations.Alice: Very comfortable sitting on early successes and parlaying that into long-term trust; she blended in well and avoided drawing suspicion even after being on multiple failing teams.
player_observations.Bob: Played cautiously and didn’t dominate table talk, which made him seem more neutral than actively good and kept him from becoming a strong counterweight to evil narratives.
player_observations.Charlie: Stayed relatively under the radar and let others drive the discussion, which worked well for Oberon in this game because no one had strong, concrete reasons to push against him.
player_observations.Eve: Took a proactive role in team discussions but got dragged into a bad mission as a good player; once that happened, she struggled to reset the table’s read on her alignment.
player_observations.Frank: Subtly guided team choices without over-asserting, which is strong Merlin play, but his caution also allowed Grace and Alice to maintain credibility longer than ideal.
player_observations.Grace: Very assertive and persuasive in mission discussions, effectively using the Morgana/Frank ambiguity to appear like a confident, informed good player and steer key teams into fails.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly kept suspicion on Alice as a Merlin candidate and was reasonably consistent in tracking mission results, but I didn’t narrow down Merlin strongly enough between Alice and Eve early, which weakened my pushes. I also trusted Frank a bit too much after Mission 2’s success and didn’t adequately re-evaluate when Mission 3 and 4 failed, so I should have been more aggressive in questioning my priors and pushing alternative team comps.

player_observations.Alice: You leaned into the Merlin/Morgana ambiguity well, especially by taking Mission 1 and then later leading a failing mission in a way that still left you plausibly good. Your table talk seemed confidently informative without overclaiming, which made you a very convincing Merlin candidate.
player_observations.Bob: You flew under the radar for a long time, especially by participating in a failing Mission 3 without drawing huge heat afterward. Your Mission 4 leadership felt calculated to anchor an evil-heavy team while still looking like you were following established trust patterns.
player_observations.Charlie: You played a fairly low-profile good game, which made it harder to build or break strong reads around you. Your votes and comments felt generally honest but not forceful enough to shift the table when it mattered.
player_observations.Eve: You were quite subtle as Merlin, not over-directing the table and often letting others take the spotlight, which unfortunately made it easier for Morgana to outshine you as the obvious information role. Your nudges were usually in the right direction but sometimes too soft to overturn the emerging consensus.
player_observations.Frank: You came across as very genuinely good, especially after the clean second mission, which made you a central anchor in many team builds. That real trust, however, also let evil hide behind you on later missions without facing enough resistance.
player_observations.Grace: You created a lot of ambiguity with your voting and team preferences, which fit Oberon well by making it hard to place you in a coherent good or evil block. Your late-game positioning contributed to confusion around which mix of players could reasonably be evil.

reflections.self_assessment: I created strong early confusion by failing Mission 1 and drawing suspicion away from the true Merlin, but I didn’t do enough later to push the team toward a more accurate Merlin guess. I should have more aggressively framed Bob as Merlin and highlighted Charlie’s subtle hints to make the final assassination more grounded in the mission history.

player_observations.Alice: Willing to take an early-risk team and play into chaos, which worked well for sowing doubt but also made you look suspicious for the rest of the game.
player_observations.Bob: Played very cautiously and looked like a solid, trustworthy core member, which made you a natural decoy for Merlin.
player_observations.Charlie: Gave careful, low-key guidance on team selections without overtalking, a classic Merlin style that blended in just enough to avoid a clean read.
player_observations.Diana: Showed consistent logic in team choices, which built credibility over time and helped anchor the good team’s decision-making.
player_observations.Frank: Stayed relatively under the radar while participating in a critical fail, which kept you from becoming the primary suspect despite being evil.
player_observations.Grace: Played straightforward and low-drama, which helped you be seen as a safe late-game pick and reinforced the good team’s trust network.

reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated reasonably well with the evil team by letting early missions pass, which helped build trust around Alice and Diana, but I failed to create enough Merlin-like signals to pull Percival fully off of Bob. I also should have pushed harder on alternative Merlin candidates after Mission 3, and my endgame reads and influence on the assassin guess were too weak.
