player_observations.Alice: Played very clean and consistent, building strong early trust by being on multiple successful missions and not over-explaining her reasoning. Her quiet reliability made her look generically good rather than particularly Merlin-y, which helped her survive to the endgame.
player_observations.Bob: Managed information subtly, giving just enough correct nudges on team selection to look competent without appearing too omniscient. His ability to stay relatively low-key while still guiding key decisions made him a very effective, well-hidden Merlin.
player_observations.Charlie: Took an active, somewhat probing approach as leader, asking questions and trying to form clear logic chains, which fit well with a cautious good role. As Percival, he seemed to track multiple Merlin candidates but didn’t hard-clear anyone publicly, which kept the board state ambiguous for evil.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as very trustworthy by staying calm and consistent across missions, especially as part of multiple successful teams. Her reasoning felt sincere rather than performative, which made her a natural anchor for good teams.
player_observations.Frank: As Mordred, he took the key risk of failing Mission 3, which created needed suspicion but didn’t fully shift the narrative away from the core trusted group. He stayed just suspicious enough to be a plausible evil without drawing overwhelming heat, but couldn’t convert that into a misdirected endgame.
player_observations.Grace: Played more independently and slightly off-tempo from the rest of the table, which fit the Oberon role but made coordination with the rest of evil harder. Her unclear alignment to both sides introduced some noise, but it didn’t translate into enough confusion to disrupt good’s emerging consensus.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently trustworthy on teams, especially by anchoring the clean missions 1, 3, and 5, which helped create a solid core of apparent good players. I could have pushed harder to publicly question the mission 2 team and more aggressively frame patterns around Diana/Frank/Alice after the triple-fail, to help good converge on the evil set faster.

player_observations.Alice: Comfortable taking leadership in mid/late game and willing to propose risky, mixed teams (including herself) even after a disastrous mission 2, which suggests confidence and a tendency to test social reads rather than play purely statistically safe.
player_observations.Bob: Played a very stabilizing, collaborative role by repeatedly going on successful missions and leading the final, clean mission 5, suggesting a style that aims to be in the center of trust and resolve ambiguity through team selection.
player_observations.Charlie: Quietly consistent presence on multiple successful missions, tending to accept being placed on teams rather than strongly driving proposals, which makes their style appear low-key but reliably pro-mission.
player_observations.Diana: Aggressive early involvement (on missions 1 and 2) and willingness to sit in the spotlight despite a catastrophic mission 2 outcome points to a bold, high-variance evil style that leans on social persuasion after mechanical suspicion appears.
player_observations.Frank: As evil without coordination, the triple-fail on mission 2 indicates a strongly disruptive approach—prioritizing maximal mission damage over subtlety—which created a lot of noise but also heavy suspicion around that whole team.
player_observations.Grace: Very controlled and precise information management as Merlin, selecting successful teams (3 and 5) without over-telegraphing and surviving to the endgame with enough ambiguity that the assassin incorrectly chose me.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed well-hidden as Merlin, feeding just enough soft trust toward Bob and Diana while not over-clearing Grace, which helped the team lock in three clean missions and dodge the assassination. I could improve by creating slightly more plausible alternative suspicions on good players to make my reads look more human and less informed, and by occasionally questioning correct teams more openly so evil has a harder time narrowing me down.

player_observations.Alice: As Oberon, your impact was necessarily limited, but you blended into the background in a way that didn’t raise obvious alarm; your low profile made you hard to read but also gave the good team little reason to reconsider their assumptions.
player_observations.Bob: You played a very straightforward, transparent good style: accepting reasonable teams and not over-pushing counter-narratives, which made it easy to trust you without making you look perfectly cleared. Your willingness to be placed on early mission teams without drama helped stabilize the game for good.
player_observations.Charlie: As Morgana, your early leadership on Mission 1 was solid because the success made you look reliable, but you didn’t follow up with enough strong, persuasive table talk to redirect trust later. You felt more reactive than proactive in shaping team compositions, which made it easier for good to lean away from you over time.
player_observations.Diana: You played a very natural good game—confident but not domineering, particularly in picking a clean Mission 2 team that reinforced trust in you. Your choices and tone came across consistent with a villager mindset, which made you an excellent anchor for team selection.
player_observations.Frank: As Mordred, you stayed sufficiently unremarkable that you never became a prime suspect for most teams, but you also didn’t create substantial doubt around the successful lineups. A bit more active misdirection—subtle pushes for slightly different team compositions—might have created more chaos for good.
player_observations.Grace: As Percival, you did well not to over-defend any single candidate as Merlin, keeping your protection relatively spread out. Your presence on Missions 2 and 3 without fails gave you strong towncred, and your balanced, non-theatrical style helped the assassin misfire on you instead of hitting the real Merlin.

reflections.self_assessment: As Oberon, I stayed relatively low-key, which helped avoid suspicion and kept me from being hard-cleared as good or hard-locked as evil. However, I could have done a better job subtly influencing team selections and discussion dynamics, especially since I lacked coordination with the other evil players and sometimes played too passively.

player_observations.Alice: Played aggressively but in a way that blended well with general table chaos; as Mordred, she managed to avoid being firmly pinned as evil even after the double-fail mission. She seemed comfortable taking calculated risks on team compositions that advanced evil’s win condition.
player_observations.Bob: His playstyle was measured and logic-driven, often grounding discussions with structured reasoning, which fits how Merlin can quietly steer outcomes without overreaching. He managed to guide teams toward some good outcomes early on while avoiding making himself an obvious night-knowledge role.
player_observations.Charlie: Leaned into a persuasive, occasionally bold style that created confusion between them and Merlin, which is very effective for Morgana. They were willing to sit in the spotlight and argue strongly, helping muddy Grace’s reads.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as genuinely puzzled at key moments and seemed to base decisions mostly on mission results and simple logic, which felt very consistent with a straightforward good player. She didn’t over-assert herself, which made her look more trustworthy but also less influential.
player_observations.Frank: Played cautiously and somewhat reactively, often following the louder voices rather than driving the table direction. This made him appear fairly neutral and non-threatening, which is typical of newer or more conservative good players.
player_observations.Grace: Her play was assertive and protective toward players she suspected might be Merlin, which fits Percival’s perspective. She seemed to rely heavily on reading tone and conviction, which made her vulnerable to Morgana’s misdirection.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly identified that Diana and Charlie were the Merlin/Morgana pair, but I was too tentative in clearly siding with Diana as the likely Merlin and pushing harder for teams that protected her reads. I also didn’t do enough to systematically clear Alice/Bob as likely good after their behaviors around Missions 1 and 4, which let evil keep more suspicion on them than they deserved.

player_observations.Alice: Played cautiously and felt genuinely frustrated by being suspected, which aligned with a good-aligned perspective, but she struggled to project strong, convincing reads that others could easily follow.
player_observations.Bob: Tried to be logical and transparent in team discussions, but occasionally tunneled too hard on suspicions, which made his arguments easier for evil to weaponize or frame as suspicious.
player_observations.Charlie: Sold the Merlin/Morgana ambiguity very well by mirroring Diana’s confidence and tone, creating a believable alternative ‘seer’ figure that made my Percival reads more difficult.
player_observations.Diana: Gave consistent, calm reads that fit the actual game state, but did so in a low-key way that didn’t scream ‘Merlin,’ which was good for survival but sometimes made it harder for good to fully rally around her.
player_observations.Frank: Flew under the radar for most of the game, avoiding sharp, polarizing statements, which allowed him to contribute to evil’s win without drawing focused suspicion.
player_observations.Grace: Took advantage of Mission 2 to quietly create confusion without overexplaining, and maintained a measured, somewhat neutral table presence that made it hard to pin her as a strong evil candidate.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed mostly under the radar as evil, especially by blending in on Mission 2 with a single fail that didn’t overexpose me, and by not drawing too much suspicion even as missions started going bad. I could improve by being more active in steering team discussions and subtly pushing suspicion onto specific good players instead of just benefiting from general confusion.

player_observations.Alice: Alice played very quietly and was hard to read, which suited Oberon but also meant she didn’t strongly influence team selection or narrative direction.
player_observations.Bob: Bob’s team choices were generally trusted, and his early involvement in successful and then mixed-result missions fit Merlin’s typical cautious style while still avoiding blatant hard-clears. His restraint in calling people out too directly helped him stay alive but also left some ambiguity that we exploited.
player_observations.Charlie: Charlie behaved like a textbook Percival, often focusing attention around who could be Merlin and trying to protect that read without being too explicit. His leadership on Mission 2 created a mix of good and evil that worked in our favor long term.
player_observations.Diana: Diana played aggressively and embraced risk, pushing teams that mixed alignments and using the double-fail Mission 3 to sow maximum confusion. Her style as Morgana sold a strong ‘possible Merlin’ aura, which helped divert attention away from Bob at key moments.
player_observations.Frank: Frank’s early success on Mission 1 gave him some credibility, but later participation on mixed teams made him second-guess his reads and hesitate on hard accusations. He seemed to rely more on mission outcomes than on social reads, which made him vulnerable to manipulated team compositions.
player_observations.Grace: Grace approached the game cautiously and seemed to look for consensus before committing to strong stances, which made her appear reasonable but not particularly leading. That hesitancy meant her suspicions didn’t significantly shift the group’s direction even when she was on the right track.

reflections.self_assessment: Coordinating the double-fail on Mission 2 with Charlie while keeping my own suspicion relatively moderate was strong, and I helped create enough confusion around Merlin’s identity that Frank was still assassinated correctly despite the late double-successes. I could improve by seeding more targeted paranoia on Grace earlier, since her reads seemed to be stabilizing the good team’s trust network in the midgame.

player_observations.Alice: Tended to anchor on early mission results and trust patterns, sticking with known team members once a mission succeeded, which made her somewhat predictable but also a stabilizing force for good.
player_observations.Bob: Played quite chaotically and independently, which fit Oberon; his unpredictability made it harder for good to form clean narratives but also made him difficult for evil teammates to leverage directly.
player_observations.Charlie: Was willing to take high-risk, high-impact lines (like the double-fail on Mission 2), and then leaned on a confident table presence to normalize suspicious outcomes afterward.
player_observations.Diana: Showed a cautious, consensus-seeking style, often following table sentiment rather than driving it, which kept her from being a primary suspect but also from strongly steering team selection.
player_observations.Frank: Played a very controlled Merlin game, hiding hard reads and blending in as a reasonable but not domineering good player, which successfully kept him from being obviously exposed until the assassination guess.
player_observations.Grace: Acted like a natural coordinator and soft leader, trying to interpret mission data and nudge the group toward consistent logic, which made her look like a likely Merlin or at least a core good voice.

reflections.self_assessment: I was too trusting of early mission proposals and didn’t push hard enough on demanding consistent logic from others after each fail. I need to be more vocal in challenging successful-looking but suspicious lineups and in re-evaluating my reads after every mission result, especially after Mission 2 and 3 pointed strongly to a concentrated evil cluster around Frank’s and Grace’s teams.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very controlled, low-key evil game: going on two missions (1 and 3) and only failing 3, which made her look safer because of the clean first mission. She leaned into the early trust from Diana and Frank and didn’t overtalk, which let her slide as a ‘reliable’ pick until the disastrous Mission 4 exposed how much evil was concentrated around her.
player_observations.Bob: As a good player who only went on the failed Mission 2, he ended up looking suspicious by association but actually played a relatively quiet, reactive game. Because he didn’t push strong alternative theories, it was easy for evil to keep him in a gray area instead of being cleared as solidly good.
player_observations.Charlie: As Oberon, he stayed quite under the radar and didn’t strongly coordinate or push agendas, which fit both a cautious good and an isolated evil profile. Joining the triple-fail Mission 4 without much resistance helped close the game for evil while keeping his earlier game low-impact and hard to read.
player_observations.Diana: Her Mission 1 team choice (Frank + Alice) inadvertently gave evil a clean success and built a lot of trust around that combination. As Percival, she was clearly trying to protect/perceive Merlin, but the early success with both Frank and Alice on it made it easier for Morgana to hide and for that trust structure to persist longer than it should have.
player_observations.Frank: As Merlin, he walked a very fine line: his team choices and mission involvement (especially Mission 3) were subtly steered but not blatantly so, which unfortunately didn’t prevent that mission from failing. His signaling was cautious enough that good didn’t fully lock onto the right evil team, and some of his apparent trust in Alice and Grace made it harder for the rest of us to break from those assumptions.
player_observations.Grace: As Morgana, she did an excellent job blending in and leveraging the Merlin/Morgana ambiguity, especially around Missions 2 and 4. Leading the final mission and including three evils while still making it feel somewhat plausible showed strong social positioning—she benefited a lot from the credibility created by earlier missions and didn’t appear overly pushy or desperate.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly trusted Frank early and pushed for the successful Mission 2 with him and Diana, but I failed to clearly and consistently signal suspicion on Alice, Bob, and Grace as the evil cluster. I also didn't do enough to help Diana (Percival) separate me from Morgana, which made it easier for evil to control the narrative late game.

player_observations.Alice: Played Morgana very credibly as a potential Merlin, taking early mission leadership and mixing in just enough risk (failing Mission 1) to look like an unlucky but active good player.
player_observations.Bob: Stayed relatively controlled and low-key for Mordred while steering mission choices at key points, especially on Mission 3 and 4, where he blended in as a ‘reasonable’ voice while pushing bad teams.
player_observations.Charlie: Played straightforwardly and transparently, reading as genuinely good but didn’t push hard enough to shape team comps, which made their honesty easier for evil to exploit rather than anchor.
player_observations.Diana: As Percival, she tried to read between me and Alice but hesitated to hard-clear me, which is understandable given the mixed signals; she generally played carefully but could have been more assertive once patterns emerged.
player_observations.Frank: Came off as very authentically good and cooperative, and his presence on the successful Mission 2 helped anchor some trust, though he could have pushed more strongly against repeating suspicious patterns in later missions.
player_observations.Grace: As Oberon, managed to look like a plausible but slightly messy good player, creating confusion without clear coordination and slipping onto the critical Mission 4 fail team without drawing decisive suspicion.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed low-profile enough that people were willing to include me on Mission 4, which gave evil a real shot to swing the game, but I didn’t help create a coherent narrative to protect Merlin’s identity or frame someone else more convincingly. I should have been more active in shaping suspicions earlier, especially around Missions 2 and 3, and I also needed to support a stronger fake-Merlin line that pointed more clearly at Bob or Eve.

player_observations.Alice: Willing to take an early risk by failing Mission 1, which created chaos but also drew a long-term shadow on that first team; felt more like a disruption piece than someone carefully managing perceptions.
player_observations.Bob: Came across consistently reasonable and trustworthy, supporting successful mission teams and reading the table well enough that he was believable as Merlin, especially by the endgame.
player_observations.Charlie: Very controlled and subtle with information; pushed or supported the right teams without being loud about it, which in hindsight was classic low-key Merlin play.
player_observations.Diana: Played like a straightforward good player: valued consistent teams after success and didn’t over-complicate narratives, which made her look reliably village-aligned.
player_observations.Eve: Took on a visible, talkative role that made her a natural candidate for being Merlin, but the early fail and her positioning made her look more like a high-activity power role, which helped draw heat away from Charlie.
player_observations.Grace: Played cautiously and didn’t force themselves into the spotlight, which made them blend into the background as a solid, unremarkable good pick for the final mission.
player_observations.Frank: N/A

reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated the Mission 3 fail in a way that didn't immediately expose me, but I failed to push enough suspicion away from Bob and instead let the table settle into a comfortable, incorrect narrative about Merlin. I also didn't do enough active agenda-setting in discussions, which meant good players controlled the framing and I ended up with a bad assassination guess on Alice instead of seriously challenging Bob’s growing credibility.

player_observations.Alice: Consistently willing to be on early teams and played in a very low-key, cooperative way, which made her look generically villagey without drawing much attention. Her quiet reliability helped good secure early successes and made it tempting to mis-assassinate her as Merlin.
player_observations.Bob: Managed information and tone extremely well, rarely overclaiming and instead nudging team compositions just enough to look reasonable. His calm, structured reasoning and willingness to include suspected players made him feel like a cautious good leader rather than an obvious Merlin.
player_observations.Charlie: Played like a classic cautious good role, asking questions and trying to rationalize team selections, which fit nicely with Percival’s info without outing it. Their balance of doubt and acceptance made them look like a thoughtful villager rather than a power role.
player_observations.Diana: Projected strong early-game trustworthiness by being on multiple successful teams and keeping her table talk simple and direct. She didn’t over-argue her reads, which made her look like a stable core good and a safe inclusion for most missions.
player_observations.Eve: Morgana was understated; she didn’t push hard, flashy reads that would scream fake Merlin, instead blending into the general good chorus. That subtlety made it harder for me to leverage her as a clear Merlin decoy in the assassination phase.
player_observations.Grace: Oberon’s presence felt more like a chaotic or disconnected read source than a coordinated evil partner, which is appropriate but made evil’s overall narrative less cohesive. Her contributions sometimes introduced noise that good could safely ignore rather than productive misdirection we could build on.

reflections.self_assessment: As Oberon, I stayed hidden effectively and didn’t contaminate the information that the other evil players were using, but I also failed to coordinate my voting and table talk in ways that subtly helped the assassin identify Merlin. I need to be more deliberate about nudging suspicion toward multiple good players and paying closer attention to how mission teams and approvals reveal Merlin’s identity.

player_observations.Alice: Very assertive in getting on critical missions and was willing to take a visible fail (Mission 4) while still maintaining plausible deniability, which fit Mordred well. Tends to lean into active leadership and can use that to steer table talk effectively.
player_observations.Bob: Played a solid information-gathering game, frequently ending up on successful teams and leveraging that to appear trustworthy. As Percival, seemed to protect Grace subtly by being consistently comfortable with her on teams while not over-defending her.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as straightforward and consistent, which made their presence on early successful missions reassuring to others. Seems to prefer a low-drama, logic-first style that makes them hard to suspect when they’re good.
player_observations.Diana: Played aggressively evil on Mission 2 with a full fail, which created chaos but also drew some attention to that team. Generally leans into bold moves and strong statements, which can be powerful but also somewhat risky.
player_observations.Eve: Maintained a very clean table image, being on multiple successful missions and not overreaching for control. Their calm, measured approach made them a natural target for the assassin, which shows how convincingly good they appeared.
player_observations.Grace: Balanced giving just enough correct reads to guide good teams while avoiding being too obviously right all the time, which is ideal Merlin play. Managed to survive suspicion long enough for good to win, indicating strong control over how much information she surfaced and when.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed relatively low-profile as Mordred, which helped keep suspicion off me, but I didn’t do enough to push the team compositions toward configurations that could fail missions without exposing the evil team. I also should have been more active in misleading Percival about Merlin’s identity and coordinating with Morgana to set up a better assassination guess.

player_observations.Alice: Played very quietly for an Oberon, which made you hard to read but also didn’t create much disruptive chaos that could benefit the evil team. Your low profile likely kept you from becoming a serious suspect, but also limited your impact.
player_observations.Bob: Your inclusion on Missions 2 and 3 with no fails suggested a very straightforward, trustworthy style that worked in your favor. You didn’t overtalk, which made it hard to build a credible case against you.
player_observations.Charlie: As Morgana on the first successful mission, you established early credibility and didn’t overplay the evil angle, which was strong. However, there wasn’t enough visible coordination with me to shape late-game narratives or to frame a stronger Merlin candidate.
player_observations.Diana: Being on all three successful missions gave you a very clean image, and you leaned into that reliability without drawing excessive attention. Your team selections and acceptance pattern looked logical from a good player perspective, which made it difficult to build suspicion on you.
player_observations.Eve: You played a very controlled Merlin game—careful enough not to be obvious, but subtly influential in getting strong teams through. The fact that we killed Grace instead of you shows you balanced giving good info with hiding just well enough.
player_observations.Grace: As Percival, you sold the idea that you could plausibly be Merlin, which successfully drew the assassination away from Eve. Your voting and table talk had a confident, informed tone that made you look like a strong info role rather than just a generic good player.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistent with a generally pro-good voting pattern and tried not to overreact, which helped me avoid looking suspicious, but I didn’t do enough to actively drive the team-building discussions or push hard alternative theories when missions started failing. I need to be more assertive about calling out suspicious patterns (especially the double-fail on Mission 2 and the single-fail on Mission 3) and coordinating with likely trusted players instead of mostly following others’ logic.

player_observations.Alice: She played very subtly evil, blending into reasonable team suggestions while managing to get onto a critical failing mission without drawing too much suspicion. Her ability to look like a reasonable pick for Mission 2 and Mission 4 shows she’s good at hiding in the middle of the pack rather than at the extremes.
player_observations.Bob: As Merlin, he balanced sharing information with staying alive, but his team preferences weren’t forceful or clear enough for the table to reliably follow them. His relatively frequent inclusion on teams and lack of strong resistance to certain lineups made it harder for good to read who he actually distrusted.
player_observations.Charlie: He leaned into a confident, slightly commanding style that fit Morgana well, creating plausible arguments that made him seem informed rather than suspicious. The double-fail on his Mission 2 team suggests he was comfortable taking high-risk, high-reward plays to quickly tilt the game in evil’s favor.
player_observations.Diana: She played like a cautious good player, willing to go on a risky team (Mission 3) but not loudly directing others, which made her seem more neutral than actively cleared. Her inclusion on multiple failing teams made her look ambiguous, and she didn’t push hard to reframe suspicion away from herself with strong counter-arguments.
player_observations.Eve: As Oberon, she came across as somewhat chaotic or hard to read, which unintentionally fit the role and made it difficult for good to confidently classify her. Getting onto the failing Mission 3 and then leading the failing Mission 4 showed she was comfortable making sharp, pivotal moves once she had the opportunity.
player_observations.Grace: As Percival, she appeared to trust the wrong signals, likely reading Charlie’s confidence as Merlin-like, which steered good away from the right deductions. Her votes and team preferences had influence, and when she leaned the wrong way, it gave evil cover to operate under her apparent endorsement.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed low-profile as Oberon and avoided drawing heat, which helped evil avoid obvious coordination tells while still securing three failed missions. However, I could have done more to subtly influence team selections and discussions, as my presence was almost too quiet and didn’t create useful misdirection for Merlin and the good team.

player_observations.Alice: Played cautiously and seemed genuinely unsure on reads, which made her look consistently good-aligned but not particularly influential in steering team choices.
player_observations.Bob: Took a proactive leadership role and appeared comfortable proposing teams, but trusted patterns a bit too much and ended up including multiple evil players on critical missions.
player_observations.Charlie: Leaned into a confident, slightly assertive style that fit Morgana well, projecting ‘fake Merlin’ energy and helping muddy good’s role reads.
player_observations.Diana: As Merlin, gave just enough resistance at key points to hint at suspicions without outing herself, but still couldn’t prevent evil-heavy teams from passing in the later missions.
player_observations.Eve: Tried to protect and interpret Merlin-like signals as Percival, but seemed torn between multiple candidates for Merlin and Morgana, which diluted their impact on table direction.
player_observations.Grace: Played Mordred in a very controlled, deliberate way—joining a failing mission without overexplaining, and blending in as a reasonable voice that good didn’t aggressively challenge.

reflections.self_assessment: I trusted the early Bob/Frank pairing too much and didn’t push hard enough to re-evaluate Eve and Diana after consecutive fails, especially after Mission 3 clearly pointed to at least one of them being evil. I did well in staying consistently pro-mission and not looking suspicious myself, but I should have advocated more strongly against including Eve on Mission 4 and pressed Charlie and Grace to consolidate a tighter good bloc.

player_observations.Alice: Stayed very low-impact as Oberon, which made you almost invisible in the discussion and thus naturally read as generically good; that quietness can be powerful but also risks being ignored in key decision moments.
player_observations.Bob: Played a very strong, controlled Merlin game—early trust in you from Mission 1 felt natural, and you managed to guide teams subtly without over-clearing too many people, though your influence didn’t quite prevent the late-game evil stack.
player_observations.Charlie: Came across as sincerely analytical and very ‘good-coded’, which fits Percival, but you could have done more to openly challenge the inclusion of Eve and Diana after multiple fails; your reads seemed close but not forcefully pushed.
player_observations.Diana: You leaned into a confident, directive style that worked well for Morgana, especially on your mission pick that double-failed; that strong presence helped you look like a central good voice while quietly anchoring evil choices.
player_observations.Eve: You played Mordred with a nice mix of cooperation and just enough ambiguity—being on the failing Mission 2 but not drawing too much heat afterward was key; you benefited a lot from not being loudly defended or loudly attacked.
player_observations.Grace: Your play felt genuinely good and fairly cautious, but somewhat reactive rather than agenda-setting; if you’d pushed your suspicions harder near Mission 4, the team composition might have shifted away from including both Charlie and Eve.

reflections.self_assessment: I did a solid job of identifying the evil team early and steering Missions 4 and 5 to success, but I clearly failed at staying hidden as Merlin, since the assassin correctly picked me. I need to better balance giving useful information with occasionally allowing ambiguity or minor "mistakes" so I don't stand out so much in the late game.

player_observations.Alice: Alice played in a straightforward, good-leaning way and stayed consistently trusted, which made her a natural anchor for multiple teams. She didn’t over-assert accusations, which made her feel safe and helped good stabilize in the later missions.
player_observations.Bob: Bob as Oberon was relatively quiet and didn’t strongly drive the table, which kept him from drawing much suspicion despite being on a failed mission. His subtlety made him look more like a confused good player than a coordinated evil one.
player_observations.Charlie: Charlie as Mordred created early chaos with the Mission 2 fail but then managed to avoid being heavily locked in as evil, spreading suspicion around effectively. His ability to blend in after a big red flag was a key part of evil’s long-term cover.
player_observations.Diana: Diana’s play felt logical and transparent, which made her very believable as good and someone I could lean on for later mission teams. She contributed to stabilizing the table and didn’t overreach, which reinforced her trustworthiness.
player_observations.Eve: Eve as Morgana did a strong job of generating confusion around reads and not being obviously linked to the other evils, helping maintain doubt about who was truly suspicious. Her presence made it harder for good to converge quickly on a clean solve.
player_observations.Grace: Grace as Percival played like a high-information good, often aligning with the correct teams, but that also risked signaling too clearly who Merlin might be. Her trust in me and how our reads lined up probably helped the assassin narrow their guess onto me.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly identified the evil trio early, but I played too cautiously in signaling that knowledge and allowed multiple failed missions to go through without strongly steering resistance away from them. I need to balance subtlety with more decisive voting and team-building, especially avoiding putting confirmed-evil players like Alice on my own team when it risks critical mission failures.

player_observations.Alice: Very assertive and effective as Mordred, slipping onto early teams and maintaining enough trust that she could be taken even by me as Merlin on Mission 3 without drawing overwhelming suspicion.
player_observations.Bob: Played a quiet, straightforward good role; his voting pattern didn't generate much heat, but he also didn’t strongly drive alternative team proposals, which made it easier for evil teams to pass.
player_observations.Charlie: As Oberon, he blended into the background well, not loudly coordinating but also not attracting strong suspicion, which helped evil stack the final mission without heavy resistance.
player_observations.Diana: As Percival, she did a solid job of looking generally trustworthy and was quickly accepted as a safe pick, but our Merlin/Morgana signals clearly weren’t resolved strongly enough in town’s favor.
player_observations.Eve: Played like a very reasonable, logic-driven good player, but her leadership on Mission 2 and inclusion of me and Grace gave evil an early inroad and some credibility to Grace.
player_observations.Grace: Extremely influential as Morgana, leveraging the Merlin/Morgana ambiguity well and using her Mission 4 leadership to confidently assemble a heavily evil-stacked team that town still let through.

reflections.self_assessment: I tunneled too hard on the wrong suspects after Mission 1 and didn’t sufficiently update my reads after the clean Mission 2 team, which actually contained both Merlin and Percival. I also failed to push hard enough against including new, unproven players on later missions (especially Mission 4), and I should have been more vocal in defending the consistently clean core.

player_observations.Alice: Played aggressively and leaned into early mission leadership, using the Mission 1 fail to create confusion without drawing too much late-game heat; her behavior was just ambiguous enough to keep suspicion split.
player_observations.Bob: Stayed relatively under the radar and leveraged being placed on the critical Mission 3 to deliver a fail at a pivotal moment, then benefited from the chaos and distrust that followed.
player_observations.Charlie: Came off as fairly low-impact and somewhat quiet, which made it easy for evil to redirect blame away from themselves and onto more active players without much resistance.
player_observations.Diana: Her voting and team preferences were quite consistent with good logic, but because she was often paired with me, our shared presence on failed missions made her look more suspicious than she deserved.
player_observations.Eve: As Merlin, she did a solid job of steering towards good-heavy teams like Mission 2 while not over-pushing her reads, though some of her soft signals were too subtle for me to fully trust in time.
player_observations.Grace: Played a very chaotic, hard-to-read game that fit Oberon well; her inclusion on the final mission felt risky in hindsight, but she managed to avoid generating enough concrete evidence against herself before that point.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed reasonably consistent with team voting and helped secure the final mission by trusting the right core of players, but I could have been more vocal in pushing back on suspicious patterns earlier, especially around Mission 1 and Mission 4. In future games, I should articulate my reads more clearly and sooner so that my influence on team selection is stronger.

player_observations.Alice: Early fail on Mission 1 from her team made her look suspicious, and she leaned into a quieter, less directive style that fit Oberon—present but not strongly steering team compositions.
player_observations.Bob: He played like a solid, proactive good player—prioritizing stable teams and ending up repeatedly on successful missions, which also made him a believable Merlin candidate and drew the assassin’s shot.
player_observations.Charlie: He subtly guided team selection toward a stable good core without over-asserting, especially from Mission 2 onward, balancing influence and caution very well as Merlin.
player_observations.Diana: She came across as straightforward and consistent, and while being on both a success and a later fail could have drawn heat, her overall voting and table talk matched a generally clear, good-aligned mindset.
player_observations.Eve: Her arc from the early fail on Mission 1 to later trying to reinsert herself into critical decisions felt like controlled misdirection—active but never quite fully trustworthy, fitting Morgana’s need to appear like an informed good player.
player_observations.Frank: He stayed relatively lower profile and only appeared on one mission—the failed Mission 4—creating just enough ambiguity to avoid being a prime suspect while still contributing to a crucial sabotage as Mordred.

reflections.self_assessment: As Oberon, I stayed low-impact enough that I wasn’t obviously suspicious, which helped keep heat off me individually. However, I didn’t do enough to subtly support the assassin’s information or create extra doubt around Merlin, and I should have paid more attention to mission team patterns to anticipate how good was reading the game.

player_observations.Alice: Consistently ended up on successful teams and projected a straightforward, trustworthy vibe, which made her a natural lightning rod for the assassin’s guess. She seemed comfortable being repeatedly picked, which reinforced the impression that she was central good rather than cautious or evasive.
player_observations.Bob: Played an extremely low-key Merlin game, avoiding the failed Mission 3 while getting onto the key successful missions, especially the final one. His lack of overt steering made him blend in as a regular good player and successfully divert the kill away from himself.
player_observations.Charlie: As Percival, he appeared willing to trust and go along with teams rather than loudly directing, which helped keep Merlin’s identity obscured. His participation on both an early safe team and the final mission suggested he had a quiet but correct read on where the safety was.
player_observations.Diana: Frequently included on successful missions, she projected a consistently reliable good-player image. Her presence on the one failed mission alongside Frank didn’t seem to draw much suspicion, indicating she maintained a solid table image throughout.
player_observations.Eve: As Morgana, she drew the assassin kill toward Alice instead of Bob, which shows she sold herself well as a Merlin candidate to Percival. However, the final guess on Alice suggests that while she created some confusion, she and the team didn’t fully lock onto Bob’s subtle Merlin play.
player_observations.Frank: As Mordred, he likely coordinated the single fail on Mission 3 while avoiding being broadly suspected afterward. Being on the only failed team but not becoming the obvious scapegoat suggests he managed his table talk and tone well enough to keep heavy heat off himself.

reflections.self_assessment: I balanced giving useful information with staying hidden reasonably well, especially by supporting the Mission 3 and 5 team compositions without overexplaining my logic. I could improve by seeding clearer, earlier suspicion on Alice and Diana after Mission 2’s triple-fail while still making it look like deduction rather than knowledge, which might have helped good coordinate more confidently on Mission 4. Overall, my signal was just subtle enough that Bob could lean the right way without making me obvious to the Assassin.

player_observations.Alice: You played aggressively and confidently, especially around Mission 2 and Mission 4, pushing yourself onto key teams in a way that looked like you were driving the game forward rather than steering it into fails. Your style leans into being a proactive leader who frames your choices as logical, which is strong as evil but also makes you a good focal point for suspicion later if missions go badly.
player_observations.Bob: You had a fairly cautious, info-gathering style, but were willing to commit when you felt a team was reasonably safe, especially on Missions 3 and 5. As Percival, you seemed to balance attention between potential Merlin candidates without tunneling too hard, which helped you keep Eve more suspicious than me in the endgame.
player_observations.Charlie: You played a straightforward, low-flash good game, not forcing yourself onto teams unnecessarily and mostly following table logic. Your decisions tended to track with revealed information rather than big gambles, which made you look consistently, quietly good and helped stabilize trust around you by the end.
player_observations.Diana: You were a very convincing early-game good voice, especially with how comfortable you looked after the success on Mission 1. The sharp contrast between that and the catastrophic triple-fail Mission 2 made your position tricky, but you still tried to maintain a narrative of shared blame rather than personal guilt, which is a very classic, social-heavy evil approach.
player_observations.Eve: You came across as sincerely analytical and open, and your willingness to go on multiple successful missions built you a strong good aura. The fact that you drew the Assassin’s shot as Merlin shows how naturally you occupied the ‘informed, slightly central’ table role without appearing too certain or omniscient.
player_observations.Frank: Your play as Oberon felt subtly detached from coordinated evil signaling, which actually made table reads on you harder because your mistakes didn’t line up cleanly with other evils’ incentives. You had moments of awkward positioning—especially around the fallout of Mission 2—that looked more like confused good than calculated evil, which is a powerful asset for Oberon when it doesn’t accidentally burn your team’s cover.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently aligned with Eve’s signals as Merlin without overexposing her, which helped keep our mission teams clean and efficient. I could improve by being a bit more vocal in sowing doubt about myself as a potential Merlin target and by pushing more structured discussion to flush out evil voting patterns.

player_observations.Alice: Played very quietly and blended into the background, which fit Oberon’s hidden-evil role but also made it hard to read or use her behavior strategically.
player_observations.Bob: Showed a very straightforward, cooperative good playstyle, trusting successful teams quickly and not overcomplicating decisions once patterns looked safe.
player_observations.Charlie: As Morgana, projected confidence and early trustworthiness, especially on Mission 1, but didn’t generate enough late-game suspicion to redirect the assassin cleanly.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as solid and trustworthy, with calm, consistent decisions on missions that reinforced the narrative of a stable good core.
player_observations.Eve: Signaled information subtly and very efficiently as Merlin, guiding team choices without drawing too much attention and successfully avoiding the assassin.
player_observations.Frank: Stayed relatively controlled and low-key as Mordred, avoiding obvious sabotage patterns but also not creating enough credible alternative Merlin candidates in the endgame.

reflections.self_assessment: I trusted Charlie-as-Morgana over Bob-as-Merlin for too long, especially after Mission 2, and didn’t push hard enough to re-center the table on Bob once patterns of double-fails and team comps emerged. I also underutilized my role knowledge as Percival by not more aggressively challenging teams that excluded Bob or leaned heavily on Alice/Charlie after they were repeatedly connected to failed missions.

player_observations.Alice: Comfortably took high-risk spots, joining Mission 2 and 4 and still avoiding hard, early suspicion despite being tied to multiple fails, which suggests a calm, low-reactive evil style that relies on others to over-explain for her.
player_observations.Bob: Played a relatively subtle Merlin, feeding just enough soft resistance to suspicious teams without sounding like he had perfect info, but perhaps so understated that it was easy for evil (and me as Percival) to discount his perspective compared to louder voices.
player_observations.Charlie: Sold the Morgana bluff very convincingly by confidently stepping into the ‘trusted core’ early and accepting heat from the double-fail Mission 2 in a way that felt almost too risky for evil, which made the deception more believable.
player_observations.Diana: Played like a straightforward, mission-focused good player—her inclusion on the failed Mission 3 and 4 teams didn’t come with strong self-defense theatrics, which made her look oddly neutral and therefore easier for evil to keep in mixed teams.
player_observations.Eve: As Oberon, blended in surprisingly well despite being disconnected from the other evil roles, joining key failing missions (3) without drawing consistent, targeted suspicion, suggesting a flexible, adaptive style rather than loudly steering the table.
player_observations.Frank: Came across as solidly good and low-drama, with a style that doesn’t over-argue reads; that quiet reliability made it harder to distinguish his true alignment but also meant he didn’t strongly shift team-building away from suspicious configurations.

reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated well with the rest of evil by taking a subtle fail on Mission 2 that created just enough doubt without overexposing myself, and then letting later missions carry the bulk of suspicion away from me. I could improve by more actively shaping the narrative in table talk—pushing stronger, proactive theories about who was evil so that my apparent confidence as a 'good' player would have been more believable and influential.

player_observations.Alice: Tended to build logically consistent teams and seemed generally trusted, which made the failed Mission 3 especially impactful for shaping suspicion away from her allies rather than herself.
player_observations.Bob: Played a straightforward, earnest style that made him look reliably good, and his leadership on Mission 4 showed he was willing to take some risks once he felt he had a solid read.
player_observations.Charlie: Blended in well as Morgana, staying involved but not overly loud, which helped keep Merlin’s information muddled and preserved ambiguity around who the real power roles were.
player_observations.Diana: As Merlin, she was cautious rather than accusatory, nudging suspicion without hard pushes, which helped her stay alive but also meant evil could keep more options open in later missions.
player_observations.Eve: Showed clear protective behavior toward certain players, which fit well with a Percival mindset, but at times her defense patterns could have given subtle hints about where she thought Merlin was.
player_observations.Frank: As Oberon, his play looked slightly off-tempo with the rest of evil, but from the table’s perspective it just registered as individual quirkiness rather than a clear alignment tell, which indirectly helped keep confusion high.

reflections.self_assessment: I think I trusted mission results too much and didn’t push hard enough to dissect who was coordinating the fails, which let the evil team shape the narrative after Mission 2. I also didn’t do enough to protect Merlin or to pressure-test the assumptions around Bob and Frank once multiple fails appeared. Next time I’ll be more vocal about alternative team comps and track voting patterns more systematically.

player_observations.Alice: Stayed under the radar as Oberon, which made it hard to read her alignment at all; her low-impact presence meant I never prioritized her as a suspect, which quietly helped evil.
player_observations.Bob: Played a very convincing Merlin, blending solid logic with just enough uncertainty to avoid being too obviously good, and consistently anchored discussion around mission results.
player_observations.Charlie: Took on an assertive, protective role as Percival, often reinforcing trust in Bob and challenging pushes against him, which helped stabilize good’s perception but may have limited exploration of other possibilities.
player_observations.Diana: As Morgana, projected confident and seemingly well-reasoned reads, which effectively competed with Bob’s information and created plausible alternative narratives that confused the table.
player_observations.Eve: Played Mordred as a flexible, adaptive presence—willing to go on suspicious teams but not over-defend herself—making her look like a reasonable risk rather than a core evil.
player_observations.Frank: Came across very genuinely good in table talk but got tangled in team selections and associations that later linked him to fails, which made him an unintentional shield for the real evil players.

reflections.self_assessment: I correctly gravitated toward the Alice/Diana/Frank block as likely good by the end, which helped secure the last two mission successes. However, I didn’t do enough earlier to distinguish between Frank and Eve as Merlin candidates and I likely left too many breadcrumbs about trusting Frank, making it easier for the assassin to lock onto him.

player_observations.Alice: Tended to be relatively trusting early, which showed in the risky Mission 2 team, but adapted well later by anchoring into a mostly good core once there was more information.
player_observations.Bob: Played a very low-key evil game, blending in by approving and succeeding early, then using a single, well-timed fail on Mission 3 to sow doubt without drawing much direct suspicion.
player_observations.Charlie: Took advantage of the hidden Mordred status by sitting in the double-fail Mission 2 team, then staying off critical late teams to avoid creating extra data points.
player_observations.Diana: Showed a cautious, logic-driven approach to team selection, and once she was on a successful team, she leaned into that structure to stabilize the good side’s mission choices.
player_observations.Eve: Played a convincing Merlin-like role, especially by being central to early information on Mission 2, which made it harder as Percival to cleanly separate her from the real Merlin.
player_observations.Frank: Demonstrated strong information accuracy in the late-game team choices, but may have signaled that insight a bit too clearly, allowing the assassin to correctly identify him as Merlin.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed mostly under the radar as evil while still being willing to appear on key teams and help secure mission fails, especially on Mission 4. I could improve by doing more explicit Merlin-baiting as Morgana to confuse Percival and by shaping a clearer narrative earlier about who I trusted, to better steer votes and suspicions.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very strong, low-key Mordred game, staying trusted enough to be repeatedly selected while slipping a key fail on Mission 3 and blending perfectly into the good team narrative.
player_observations.Bob: Played cautiously and seemed risk-averse, not pushing strong accusations, which made them look generally good but also meant they didn’t strongly drive the table’s logic.
player_observations.Charlie: As Oberon, came off as unpredictable and somewhat detached from the core logic, which created noise but didn’t clearly signal alignment either way.
player_observations.Diana: As Percival, appeared to be actively reading signals but didn’t successfully distinguish between Merlin and Morgana, which helped evil stay hidden and protected Frank.
player_observations.Eve: Played like a straightforward good, consistently choosing teams that looked reasonable from a surface perspective, which made her appear trustworthy but also a bit readable.
player_observations.Frank: As Merlin, did excellent subtle steering—he avoided obvious hard calls while still guiding team selections enough that good often looked reasonable, though he ultimately wasn’t protected from evil’s win.

reflections.self_assessment: I stayed low-key enough as Oberon that no one seemed to seriously suspect I was evil, which helped the overall misinformation and let other evils take more visible risks. I could improve by being more proactively influential in team discussions without drawing suspicion, especially around Missions 2 and 4 where I mostly followed rather than subtly steering.

player_observations.Alice: Very assertive in pushing teams and narratives, using her Morgana role to confidently occupy the Merlin-claim space and keep attention off actual role logic. She’s comfortable taking heat as long as it creates confusion about information sources.
player_observations.Bob: Plays a more measured Mordred, often appearing reasonable and logic-driven, which makes his proposals feel safe to good players. He’s good at placing exactly one fail at pivotal moments (like Mission 3) to maximize doubt without revealing a clear pattern.
player_observations.Charlie: Tended to be cautious and somewhat reactive, often deferring to stronger voices rather than driving team composition. This made Charlie appear more genuine but also easier to influence in critical votes.
player_observations.Diana: As Percival, she was very focused on reading Merlin signals and cross-checking behavior, which made her skeptical but occasionally over-tunneled on a few suspects. She tried to anchor the table with logic but didn’t always adjust quickly when new mission info arrived.
player_observations.Eve: Played Merlin subtly, avoiding hard calls early and instead nudging team compositions through soft suggestions. Her low-key style protected her identity well but also left just enough ambiguity for evil to exploit late.
player_observations.Frank: Came across as straightforward and earnest, often trusting apparent logic and previous mission results rather than deep-reading player intentions. This openness made him a stabilizing presence but also a bit susceptible to evil-led framing of the narrative.
